AI-assisted summary President Trump proposed selling 'gold cards' for $5 million each, granting U.S. residency with a path to citizenship.

Trump argues the program would boost the economy by attracting wealthy individuals who would invest and create jobs.

But there are consequences for essentially selling American citizenship to the highest bidder.

President Donald Trump’s price for U.S. citizenship is $5 million each? “El Chapo” Guzman or any wealthy terrorist would like a word.

This isn’t some sort of nasty joke from a deranged social media influencer.

It’s a real proposal that Trump unveiled on Tuesday, saying he knows “some Russian oligarchs that are very nice people” who could “possibly” be eligible.

His retort to a question in the Oval Office crystalizes the absurdity and danger of selling citizenship to the highest bidder.

Trump’s proposal is to sell U.S. residency “gold cards” for $5 million each with a path to citizenship, presumably depending on the investment made in America.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Drug dealers and terrorists would love a 'gold card'

That opens the bidding to anyone with plenty of cash, such as Russian oligarchs and the likes of “El Chapo” Guzman, the kingpin responsible for much of the fentanyl smuggled into the U.S.

That kingpin is serving a life sentence in a U.S. prison, but the point here is that anyone with loads of cash and bad intentions could get their hands on Trump’s “gold cards” and do us a lot of harm.

None of that fazes Trump, of course, who’s putting America and everything in it up for sale.

“Wealthy people will be coming into our country by buying this card,” Trump said. “They’ll be wealthy, and they’ll be successful, and they’ll be spending a lot of money and paying a lot of taxes and employing a lot of people.”

“We think it’s going to be extremely successful,” Trump added, estimating that he could sell a million of those “gold cards.”

Existing EB-5 program is already rife with abuse

How would Trump do it?

He’d replace the sweet deal known as the EB-5 program, which grants U.S. residency to foreigners who invest at least $900,000 or $1.8 million, depending on the area.

By many accounts, that program, which had quotas and was designed in part to lure investment to underserved areas such as rural America, has been plagued by fraud and abuse.

Now imagine lifting the quotas and just let in anyone who can pay with no restrictions.

Opinion:Arizona's hunt for migrants is vigilantism on steroids

We all know by now that the only thing that matters to Trump and his billionaire henchman Elon Musk is money — for their own pocketbooks and to finance tax cuts for their wealthy pals.

Forget the fact that Trump wants to sell his “gold cards” while deporting “millions and millions” of people, many of them poor and being returned to brutal countries where they could face death.

There’s no sympathy for the poor, the desperate fleeing violence and other calamities.

What's next for Trump? Selling the White House?

But is it too much to ask MAGA to see the danger of auctioning entry to the U.S.? After all, Trump sold them the idea of shutting down America’s borders to keep the country safe, right?

Nah, that’s rhetorical. They see nothing wrong with Trump selling America — and possibly our safety — to the highest bidder.

It’s unclear whether Trump can legally carry out his proposal, but he seems sure of it.

So, what’s next? Selling the White House to the highest bidder?

Elvia Díaz is editorial page editor for The Arizona Republic and azcentral. Reach her at 602-444-8606 or elvia.diaz@arizonarepublic.com. Follow her on X, (formerly Twitter), @elviadiaz1.

search_result.title: Pfizer vaccine: Three-dose Covid-19 vaccine produces strong ...
search_result.text:
CNN —

Three child-size doses of the Pfizer/BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine appeared to be safe and showed a strong immune response in children ages 6 months to 5 years, the companies said Monday. The vaccine makers said they will finish submitting the trial data to the US Food and Drug Administration this week.

The Phase 2/3 trial included 1,678 children who received a third vaccine dose during the period when the Omicron coronavirus variant dominated. Antibody levels tested one month after the third dose showed that the vaccine produced a similar immune response as two doses in 16- to 25-year-olds, the companies said. The data has not been peer-reviewed or published in a professional journal.

Midtrial results found vaccine efficacy of 80.3% against symptomatic Covid-19 in this young age group. The companies identified 10 symptomatic cases at least seven days after the third dose. However, the efficacy rate won’t be finalized until at least 21 symptomatic cases are found in the vaccine group and compared with the number of symptomatic cases in the placebo group.

The companies said that three child-size doses for this age group were “well-tolerated” and that no new safety signals were identified.

“These topline safety, immunogenicity and efficacy data are encouraging, and we look forward to soon completing our submissions to regulators globally with the hope of making this vaccine available to younger children as quickly as possible, subject to regulatory authorization,” Pfizer Chairman and CEO Albert Bourla said in a statement.

The vaccine doses for these children are smaller than those used in older age groups. People 12 and older receive two doses of a 30-microgram vaccine, and children ages 5 to 12 receive two doses of a 10-microgram vaccine. Both of those age groups are eligible for booster doses.

For children 6 months to 5 years, the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine is three 3-microgram doses. The initial two doses were given three weeks apart, and the third dose was given at least two months after their second dose.

Dr. William Schaffner, a professor in the Division of Infectious Diseases at Vanderbilt University School of Medicine, said Monday that vaccine scientists have been careful to adjust the dose for younger children to get “a good effect with a minimum of side effects.”

“We’re thinking of this as a three-dose vaccine, and the preliminary data acquired during the Omicron era say it’s actually 80% effective,” Schaffner told CNN’s Brianna Keilar. “We will want to look at that very carefully, but so far, that’s good news.”

Children younger than 5 are the only age group not eligible for vaccination against Covid-19. The vaccine for this age group was delayed when results of a two-dose series of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine didn’t provide the expected level of protection. The companies said they would amend the trial to add a third dose.

Get CNN Health's weekly newsletter Sign up here to get The Results Are In with Dr. Sanjay Gupta every Tuesday from the CNN Health team.

In February, the US Food and Drug Administration asked the companies to submit a request for emergency use authorization based on the two-dose data but then postponed a meeting of the agency’s vaccine advisory board so the third-dose data could be considered.

The FDA said Monday that it will convene its Vaccines and Related Biological Products Advisory Committee on June 14 to discuss Moderna’s Covid-19 vaccine EUA request for people ages 6 years through 17. On June 15, the committee will discuss Moderna and Pfizer’s EUA requests for vaccines for younger children.

Moderna submitted its vaccine data for children 6 months through 5 years of age to the FDA in late April. Moderna’s submission is based on two 25-microgram doses given 28 days apart.

search_result.title: Party on! Non-Christians don't Scrooge on Christmas fun
search_result.text:
Cathy Lynn Grossman, USA TODAY

Followers of other faiths and atheists, too, celebrate with trees, gifts, lights and more

Seven in 10 non-Christians will give Christmas gifts and share Christmas dinner

Most will put up a tree and decorate their home and some even go to church

This week was a Christmas-for-all celebration, and you need not be Christian to party.

Many atheists, Hindus, Jews and Muslims joined in the December fun like pop culture tourists. They feasted, they partied and they piled gifts under Christmas trees. After all, why Scrooge on joy?

It's not that other religions lack for fun winter holy days of their own. By Christmas Eve, Jews had wrapped up eight nights of Hanukkah candle-lighting and Hindus enjoyed their Diwali lanterns in November -- both festivals of light and goodness triumphing over evil. Muslims feasted for the Eid Al-Adha in October, celebrating the patriarch Abraham's devotion to God's commands.

And Every Day is an Atheist Holiday, boasts the latest book title from Vegas magician Penn Jillette, an outspoken unbeliever. But if his young children asked for a tree again this year, by golly (not by God) they'd get one, he says.

Jill Lightner and Tom Marshall, an atheist couple in Seattle, will deck their halls, hang a hot pink plaster angel atop their ornament-laden tree, top the statues by their doorway with Santa hats, and give homemade Advent calendars to neighboring kids.

Suhag Shukla, executive director of the Hindu American Foundation, hung a hand-made foam elephant, representing Ganesha, the Hindu lord of wisdom and new beginnings, on a Christmas tree in her family's Philadelphia home.

Sandy Silva, who is Jewish, lit the Hanukkah menorah at her Kansas City home. But when her new puppy made a holiday visit to St. Louis, it would have a red Christmas sweater if the weather turned chilly.

"I'm very much into the beauty and sparkling lights of a commercial Christmas season," says Silva. To her it signifies "a belief shared by both religions that hope can burn in every heart to sustain us."

About 27% of Americans do not identify with any Christian tradition. While some follow Judaism, Hinduism, Islam or other faiths or philosophies, nearly 20%, believe "nothing in particular," according to 2012 research from the Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life.

That's no bar to partying, according to a survey of December celebrations by LifeWay Research, a Nashville,Tenn., evangelical research agency. Among people with no Christian identity, they found:

-- 74% give Christmas gifts to family or friends.

-- 72% gather for a Christmas dinner with loved ones

-- 62% put up a Christmas tree

-- 56% decorate their home

-- 23% encourage belief in Santa

Some even get close to the Christ-centered heart of Christmas: 11% attend a Christmas Eve or Christmas Day worship service and 9% say they encourage belief in Jesus Christ as savior. This may be because about 11% of non-Christians told LifeWay they were wed to a Christian.

LifeWay Research director Scott McConnell has a theory about the 8% on non-Christians who say they buy Advent calendars to count down the days to the birth of Jesus. When he looked at Advent calendars on Amazon, he found "only one has a nativity on it. (There are) lots of Santa, toys, and chocolate. Who wouldn't like that?"

Every year nearly 80% of U.S. households put up a tree, according to polls commissioned by the National Christmas Tree Association. But among those who do not, only 7% cited religious reasons for skipping it. When they were asked why, most said they were traveling, too busy, no longer entertaining tots at home, or simply not in the mood for an evergreen. .

Jillette, whose book excoriates organized religion and touts invented dates such as "Chiquita Banana Wednesday," and Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland invention of the "unbirthday," is in the mood for whatever his children, ages six and seven, will enjoy.

If that means a big evergreen from a Christmas tree lot, well, okay. They had a tree last year, loaded with colorful ornaments. He says, "It was just like getting a pumpkin for Halloween -- secular fun. I'm not overly sensitive to it. It's not a third rail issue for me. If the kids want to check out a church some day, I'm okay with that, too, I like to be as inclusive as possible," says Jillette.

He'll be on stage with the Penn & Teller show both Christmas Eve and Christmas day before taking off for New Years. January 1 is Jillette's preferred party day "because the calendar turns over and you start fresh." They launch balloons to remember loved ones who have died, feast and shower the children in gifts. "We have already had a week to see what gifts were the most successful with their Christian and Jewish friends and then we can just swoop in and go over the top with the best."

Gifts are often the allure of Christmas-for-all spirit. There are no religious bounds on generosity.

Hadeel Masseoud, a Muslim mom writing for a Disney-sponsored parenting site, points out that, while, Muslims exchange gifts during their two major holidays, both known as Eid, they also respect Jesus as a prophet of God so celebrating his birth with a few more gifts "is not technically against any Islamic principles."

Decorations get a Muslim twist: On line companies offer dozens of Muslim ornaments including one that proclaims "Peace be upon you" in Arabic calligraphy.

Suhag Shukla grew up with her extended Hindu family putting up lights and giving the traditional gifts of candy, jewelry and new clothing for Dwali -- then leaving the lights up through January.

On Christmas, under the family's tree (always an artificial one, she says, "because Hinduism teaches respect for the earth) her dad or an uncle dressed as Santa Claus to distribute "Secret Santa" gifts among all the cousins.

Shukla still has the hand-me-down suit, too big for her teenage sons. While her boys got their gifts at Diwali, she says, come Christmas, they will get one or two small gifts more.

"Hinduism is a pluralistic tradition. There is a quiet confidence in knowing you can partake in celebrations with others without sacrificing your own belief that there are multiple paths to understanding the Divine," Shukla says.

To Jill Lightner, understanding the divine is "irrelevant any day of the year" but she still devotes most of December to sharing great food and giving to friends, neighbors and charities.

The couple enjoys hanging "crazy lights everywhere" and putting up stockings, a tree loaded with ornaments topped with a star, and a Filipino parol lantern glowing over the front door. To the faithful, a parol represents the star of Bethlehem, "but we love it for its twinkling awesomeness," she says.

Ahem. That's not just awesomeness, says Pope Benedict XVI. On Friday, when the Christmas tree for St. Peter's Square was set up, he said its lights symbolize and recall, "God became man and came among us to dispel the shadows of sin, bringing His divine light to humanity."

Not everyone sees the light that way, says atheist Robert Crenshaw,a corporate training consultant and a rock band drummer. He put out an Atheist Christmas CD featuring his own compositions, liner notes that intone solemnly about the significance of the cycles of the year in nature and a photo of him as a happy tot on Santa's knee.

"You don't have to think there's a God in the sky to love Christmas. It's okay not to buy into the literal Christian meaning of the holiday," says Crenshaw, of Oak Park, Mich.

But "Christmas-for-all," minus Christ, is a problem to those who take a serious stand on the theology of the holy day such as Rev. Michael Horton, professor at Westminster Seminary in Escondido, Calif., and host of The White Horse Inn, a radio talk show on evangelical theology theology.

The gigantic American Christmas has trivialized the birth of a savior into cultural superficiality for all, a philosophy that is "as innocuous as possible, he says.

"When Jews or agnostics or atheists want to celebrate a winter event, that makes perfect sense. But if Christmas has come to mean something even atheists can celebrate, if it is so far removed from the birth of Christ that it no longer has a serious religious meaning," Horton says, "that's not respect for Christmas, that's assimilation."

Carin Agiman,

who calls herself a non-observant Jew, assimilated one totally secular Christmas-season tradition --the ugly sweater party.

Agiman, a Berkeley, Calif., based entrepreneur, created a company, Geltfiend, to sell sweaters decorated with the spinning top and menorah -- essentials of Hanukkah -- and one of a snowman dressed as a Hassidic Jew with a black hat and side curls. "Jews get cold, too!" she says.

search_result.title: 1,301 Hajj participants died in pilgrimage to Mecca because of heat
search_result.text:
The annual Muslim pilgrimage to the sacred city of Mecca that wrapped up last week became a death march for over 1,300 Hajj participants who died in temperatures that climbed above 124 degrees.

Saudi Arabia's health minister Fahad Al-Jalajel, who on Sunday announced a death total of 1,301, blamed the fatalities on pilgrims "walking long distances under direct sunlight without adequate shelter or comfort."

The 5-6 day odyssey of hiking and prayer drew almost 2 million pilgrims from around the world. Fatalities included a number of elderly people and those suffering from chronic diseases, A-Jalajel said. About 83% of the fatalities were among people who were not authorized to make the pilgrimage, he said.

"It's only by God's mercy that I survived, because it was incredibly hot," Aisha Idris, a Nigerian pilgrim, told the BBC.

More than 650 of those who died were Egyptian; at least two were American.

Hajj is the fifth of pillar of Islam, and all Muslims are expected to make the pligrimage at least once in their lives. Maryland residents Alieu Dausy Wurie, 71, and wife Isatu Tejan Wurie, 65, spent $23,000 on an all-inclusive travel package through a tour company registered in the state.

“They saved their whole lives for this,” Saida Wurie told CNN.

Maryland couple's death ruled 'natural causes'

Wurie told CNN her parents were in Saudi Arabia when she learned via the family group chat that the tour company did not provide the proper transportation or credentials to be authorized for the pilgrimage. A man on their tour group contacted Saida Wurie to say her parents were missing on Mount Arafat after her father said that he could not continue.

Wurie said she was later contacted by U.S. Consulate officials in Jeddah saying they were notified by the Saudi Interior Ministry that her parents had died of "natural causes." The State Department, contacted by USA TODAY, would say only that "we can confirm the deaths of multiple U.S. citizens in Saudi Arabia. We offer our sincerest condolences to the families on their loss. We stand ready to provide all appropriate consular assistance."

Egypt to prosecute tourism companies

Egyptian officials said the high number of deaths, most of them among unregistered pilgrims, stemmed from some companies that used a "personal visit visa (that) prevents its holders from entering Mecca" via official channels.

Prime Minister Moustafa Madbouly ordered the revocation of licenses for 16 tourism companies that provided packages for Hajj pilgrims who were not registered for the event. He also instructed that the officials of these companies be referred to prosecutors and the companies be fined to compensate the families of the deceased pilgrims.

Authorities in Jordan said they, too, had detained several travel agents who arranged unofficial travel of Muslim pilgrims.

Hajj heat deaths:500 Egyptian pilgrims perish in 124-degree temps

Hajj has seen tragedy before

Catastrophic deaths at Hajj are not new. A stampede in 2015 killed more than 2,200 people, and another stampede in 1990 killed over 1,400 people. Four years later a stampede killed 270 people. A tent fire in 1997 killed 347. A protest turned violent in 1998, leading to the deaths of 400 pilgrims. In 2009, 77 pilgrims were killed in floods.

Contributing: Reuters

search_result.title: Recap: The pope in Philadelphia, Day 2
search_result.text:
The News Journal

Pope Francis wrapped up his historic visit to Philadelphia on Sunday, Sept. 27. Our team of reporters and visual journalists chronicled the pontiff's trip. Check out the recap of Day 1.

9:39 p.m.

About 30 buses pack the Delaware Welcome Center Travel Plaza off I-95 near Newark.

7:50 p.m.

Pope Francis has departed Philadelphia. The pope made the most of his last day in the United States, packing in appearances both scheduled and unscheduled in Philadelphia on Sunday.

Here’s what he did:

— Met privately with five survivors of sex abuse, promising them that those responsible will be held accountable.

— Spoke to about 300 bishops who had participated in the World Meeting of Families.

— Posed for photo with seminarians to recreate 1979 image that featured Pope John Paul II.

— Met with 100 inmates at a city jail, telling them to use their time behind bars to get their lives back on track.

— Blessed a new statue at Saint Joseph’s University honoring the relationship between Catholics and Jews.

— Traveled in his popemobile along Philadelphia’s Benjamin Franklin Parkway, kissing many babies along the way.

— Visited a “knot grotto,” an art project outside the city’s Roman Catholic cathedral showcasing more than 100,000 knots, each representing a personal hardship or societal challenge.

— Celebrated Mass for hundreds of thousands of people, telling them that everyone should be open to miracles of love for the sake of families around the world.

— Gave farewell speech at airport before his departure to Rome, thanking church leaders and others in Washington and New York for their work to organize his trip. – Associated Press

7:34 p.m.

7:30 p.m.

Pope Francis getting ready to depart Philadelphia, capping a busy two-day trip that had the pontiff crisscrossing the city. The Philadelphia portion was the last leg of a 10-day visit to Cuba and the U.S.

The pontiff Sunday met with survivors of sex abuse and spoke to 300 bishops at Charles Borromeo seminary, where he spent the night Saturday. He later met with 100 inmates at Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility, where convicts built a walnut chair for him.

“This time in your life can only have one purpose: to give you a hand in getting back on the right road, to give you a hand to help you rejoin society," he said.

He then delivered a public Mass in front of the Philadelphia Art Museum, attracting thousands of faithful.

His trip ended at Atlantic Aviation, a private aircraft terminal at Philadelphia International Airport, where he landed Saturday and met with 500 organizers of the World Families conference. Vice President Joe Biden and his wife Jill were in attendance.

“May God bless you all. May God bless America,” the pope said at the end of his remarks, to thunderous applause and cheers from those gathered.

He departed on a charted Boeing 777 American Airlines jet christened Shepherd One. Earlier on his trip, American took the pope from Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York.

An American Airlines spokesman told the Associated Press this month that the plane was chartered by the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops. He said the pilots and other crew members are American Airlines employees from around the country and represent different religions.

American last carried a pope, John Paul II, in 1993, flying him from Denver to Rome. Pope Francis used Alitalia to fly from Rome to Cuba on and on to Washington on Tuesday.

American plans to put the plane back into regular use after the Pope goes home, he said.

7:26 p.m.

After his first visit to the United States, Pope Francis is on his way back to Rome.

The pontiff boarded his plane at Philadelphia International Airport shortly before 7:30 p.m. Sunday, with a final farewell from Vice President Joe Biden and other delegates from the World Meeting of Families. – Brittany Horn

7:17 p.m.

Dignitaries including Philadelphia Mayor Michael A. Nutter, Pennsylvania Gov. Tom Wolf and Vice President Joe Biden are on the airport tarmac awaiting Pope Francis before his departure. – Chris Coates

7:16 p.m.

7:12 p.m.

Kevin Malloy and his family waited almost four hours in line to not see the pope today.

"We literally only moved a block and a half and we were about a half a block away when we gave up," said Malloy, 62, a University of Delaware graduate.

Thousands waited packed together to get a glimpse of the pope to no avail. After heading back to 30th Street station, Malloy and his family found themselves in another incredibly long line - except, this time they were in the front.

"I think he's phenomenal and engaging," said Malloy. "He gets people excited to go to church instead of driving them away." – Madison Goebel

7:10 p.m.

7:00 p.m.

People are leaving the parkway in droves and walking toward 30th Street station. Near JFK Blvd., Keith Hunter, from Pottstown, Pennsylvania, said good planning is allowing walkers to move easily despite the crowds.

"So far the everything's been smooth," he said. "The police have done a great job." – Karl Baker

6:53 p.m.

Following the conclusion of the Papal Mass and the Pope Francis' departure to the airport, lines have gone from security to SEPTA.

6:45 p.m.

As people leave Ben Franklin Parkway after Pope Francis delivered Mass, a mess is left behind from the crowd. – Meghan Montemurro

6:42 p.m.

Pope Francis is thanking organizers of the World Meeting of Families and addressing Vice President Joe Biden, who is seated with wife Jill Biden.

“Mr. Vice President, I ask you to renew my gratitude to President Obama,” the pope said.

6:33 p.m.

Pope Francis has arrived to Philadelphia International Airport.

6:24 p.m.

People are streaming toward SEPTA stations in downtown Philadelphia.

On Broad Street, crowds watching the Mass on Jumbotrons stayed quiet during the Mass. Children could be heard playing as their parents watched the images on television.

When the Mass ended, the crowd began dispersing. – Saranac Hale Spencer

6:23 p.m.

6:20 p.m.

Major preparations have begun at the Philadelphia International Airport, where the pope is scheduled to depart in less than two hours.

Officials are beginning to roll out the red carpet that Pope Francis before boarding the plane and returning to Rome.

Members of the Cardinal O'Hara High School Marching Band, from Philadelphia, are warming up in preparation for a send-off performance for the pope.

Senior co-drum majors Elizabeth Bradley and Caroline D'Amico will present the pontiff with bouquets of flowers.

"I love him," Bradley, 18, said. "He's so well connected to the church and the Catholic faith." – Brittany Horn

6:15 p.m.

After 26 hours, 100 gallons of gas, and four hours in line, 24-year-old Carlos Licona was stuck less than a block from the general public entrance to the papal parade.

"I'm okay with it, I'm just hanging out with my friends and making jokes and singing," said Licona, from the University of Texas at Austin. "We're just doing stuff that we would be doing at home anyway.

Licona and six of his friends began driving from Texas on Friday afternoon and arrived this morning. He's part of the Shoenstatt Movement, a religious leadership organization.

Licona plans to join the seminary and become a leader in the organization after finishing his final year of grad school.

"I can't imagine devoting my life to anything else," he said. – Kristine Iannelli

6:01 p.m.

6:00 p.m.

Pope Francis is leaving the parkway where he celebrated Mass for hundreds of thousands of people, on his way to the airport after a 10-day trip to Cuba and the United States.

As he finished Mass, he made a request with a smile: “I ask you to pray for me. Don’t forget.”

He will meet privately before his flight to Rome with about 400 leaders of the World Meeting of Families, supporters and other volunteers who helped organize his trip to Philadelphia.

As people start leaving the Mass, crews are going around with waste carts emptying filled garbage and recycling cans. Hawkers are selling water, soda and papal merchandise.

Francis said in his homily at the Mass that everyone should be open to miracles of love for the sake of families around the world. – Associated Press

5:52 p.m.

Pope Francis has finished his outdoor Mass, which was attended by thousands of pilgrims.

Many were far removed from the altar and watched the event on jumbo televisions. Those who had tickets to the viewing area closest to the stage had to endure long security lines.

The Mass had no weather problems, despite a slight chance of rain being forecast.

The pope is scheduled to meet with organizers of the World Meeting of Families at 7 p.m. The meeting is at Atlantic Aviation at Philadelphia International Airport, where Pope Francis landed on Saturday aboard an American Airlines charter plane, dubbed Shepherd One.

The festival is the original reason the pontiff scheduled his U.S. visit. The global gathering of Catholics is held every three years. Pope Francis at the Mass Sunday announced the 2018 meeting will be in Dublin, Ireland.

The pope is anticipated to depart for Rome at 8 p.m. Vice President Joe Biden and his wife Jill are expected to be at the farewell ceremony. – Associated Press

5:44 p.m.

Church officials say the next World Meeting of Families will be held in Dublin, Ireland, in 2018.

Ireland is ground zero for the church's clergy sex abuse crisis outside of the United States. The overwhelmingly Catholic country recently legalized gay marriage.

Archbishop Eamon Martin, the Catholic primate for Ireland, says he is delighted to hear the news.

He says Dublin Archbishop Diarmuid Martin was in Philadelphia with a delegation from Ireland to hear from Francis directly. – Associated Press

5:41 p.m.

Philadelphia Archbishop Charles Chaput is thanking the crowd gathered at the Ben Franklin Parkway.

"None of us will forget these days for the rest of our lives,” he said. – Chris Coates

5:39 p.m.

5:25 p.m.

A number of priest under yellow and white umbrellas took to the masses along Benjamin Franklin Parkway to distribute the sacramental bread, sometimes called the body of Christ, during the pontiff's Mass. – Esteban Parra

5:15 p.m.

Scores of priests, bishops and volunteer Eucharistic ministers are fanning out to administer communion to the throngs of people attending the papal Mass in Philadelphia.

Attendants with white and yellow umbrellas are next to those giving communion so parishioners can see where to navigate in the crowd.

A group of cloistered nuns at the suburban Monastery of St. Clare had put in extra shifts to help prepare for Pope Francis’ visit, baking 100,000 communion hosts for the Mass.

Hundreds of thousands of people crammed into the area around the Benjamin Franklin Parkway on Sunday. Tens of thousands more who weren’t able to make it through security before the Mass began either gave up and turned around or made their way to watch the event on one of several gigantic video screens dotting the city. – Associated Press

5:09 p.m.

Pope Francis is preparing for communion during his open-air Mass. The Mass is a vibrant tableau of brilliant gold, green and white in evening sunlight.

Francis earlier told his listeners that their presence itself was "a kind of miracle in today's world," an affirmation of the family and the power of love. – Associated Press

4:55 p.m.

4:52 p.m.

Pope Francis concluded his homily by saying: “Anyone who wants to bring into this world a family which teaches children to be excited by every gesture which is aimed at overcoming evil – a family which shows that the spirit is alive and at work – will encounter and find our gratitude and appreciation.

"Regardless of what people, region, or religion to which they belong, may God grant all of us to be prophets of the joy of the gospel of the family and of the love of the family, to be prophets as the Lord’s disciples, the grace to be worthy of this purity of heart which is not scandalized by the gospel. May it be so.”

Read the full text of the pope's homily, as prepared for delivery:

4:41 p.m.

Pope Francis in his homily is encouraging those gathered to have courage to follow their faith.

“Faith grows when it is practiced and it is shaped by love. That is why our families, our homes, are true domestic churches. These are the right place for faith to become life, and for faith to grow in life,” the pope said.

“Jesus tells us not to hold back these little miracles. Instead, he wants us to encourage them, to make them grow. He asks us to go through life, as life presents itself, encouraging all these little signs of love as signs of his own living and active presence in our world.”

The pope is celebrating Mass in the final portion of this tour of the U.S. After the Mass, Pope Francis is scheduled to meet with organizers and volunteers of the World Meeting of Families at 7 p.m. His flight to Rome is expected to depart at 8 p.m.

4:33 p.m.

Michael Wozniak said the papal visit has been great for his favorite bar.

The Pub on Passyunk, where Wozniak is a regular, hosted an East Passyunk block party both Saturday and Sunday.The "Holy Wooder" was his favorite papal themed beer, so far, he said, calling it "a strong Belgium."

"It was good. It packs a punch," Wozniak said. "So if you have a few of those you're good."

The owner of The Pub, John Warner, said it is rumored the pope had one of the "Holy Wooder" kegs sent to where he was staying.

"If the pope does have one of the beers I think that is amazing," Wozniak said. "One more reason to love the pope, he's already lovable, but one more reason." – Amy Hopkins

4:24 p.m.

Hasan Minhaj, with a Pope Francis doll in one hand and a candle in the other, is filming a bit for the Daily Show among the hundreds of people watching the Mass on a jumbotron set up on Broad Street in Philadelphia.

With him are half-a-dozen cameramen and producers with props including a pope hat. – Saranac Hale Spencer

4:10 p.m.

The Mass on the Ben Franklin Parkway has started.

Pope Francis, wearing green vestments, entered the stage constructed at the foot of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the same platform where the Festival of Families concert was held Saturday night.

Crowds had to go through airport-style security and bag searches.

Before the Mass, the pope stopped at an art installation at Philadelphia's Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul. The work included 30,000 white knotted ribbons, each representing a personal hardship or societal challenge.

4:02 p.m.

Parishioners at Lewes’ St. Jude the Apostle who didn’t journey to Philadelphia to see Pope Francis’s public mass on Sunday made arrangements for Philly, and the mass, to come to them.

The large Catholic church held a ‘Francisfest’ Sunday, showing an NBC affiliate’s live coverage of the events in Philly and serving soft pretzels, hoagies and Tastycakes. In a back room, kids folded miters – the headgear of bishops and popes – out of paper. Attendees paid their way in with canned goods for a food pantry.

Kathy Ebner, the church’s spiritual director, said in April and May, the church started to arrange for buses to take parishioners to Philadelphia for the events. But they grew discouraged by the logistics involved, she said, and the long distances in the city people would have to walk to take part.

“This didn’t sound like something a parish of mostly senior citizens could do,” Ebner said.

Thomas A. Flowers, the church’s pastor, said a planning council of church members came up with the idea of a Philly-themed get-together in the church hall instead.

“I’m sure we’ll be quiet during the homily and the consecration,” Flowers said. “Other than that, we want people to have a good time.” – James Fisher

3:48 p.m.

3:46 p.m.

St. Elizabeth Ann Seton parishioner Jane Muchai staked her claim along one of the less crowded stretches of the papal parade route in Logan Square. A Delawarean for four years, and originally from Kenya, she said she missed seeing Pope John Paul II each time he visited her home country in the 1980s and 90s.

After a two hour wait in the security line, she was worried that once again she'd miss her opportunity for a glimpse of the pontiff.

But as yells from the crowd grew louder around the square, she could tell that Pope Francis was approaching. Among a sea of onlookers pointing their cell phone cameras, she finally got her chance.

"That's what I've been waiting for," Muchai said. "I've seen him now." – Karl Baker

3:41 p.m.

Pope Francis is making his way through downtown Philadelphia in the popemobile before celebrating an outdoor Mass. An estimated 1 million people are expected to attend the final public event of his 10-day trip to the U.S. and Cuba.

The pontiff kissed several babies along the route, where crowds have been gathering all day.

About 10,000 volunteers are helping with the Mass, including ushers, guides, choral singers and Eucharistic ministers who will pass out communion. Twenty-eight members of the Wilmington Diocese are in the papal choir.

Some worshipers have reported waiting for several hours to pass through security checkpoints. – Chris Coates

3:37 p.m.

Manuel Diaz and Roxana Vargas, who is six months pregnant, traveled 3,000 miles with their two young children, from Vancouver, to see the pope in Philadelphia.



The pontiff passed by them on the parkway on Saturday and with all the excitement of the thousands of people around them, "we could feel the Spirit," Vargas said.



That moment made the whole trip worth it, said Diaz. It "paid the flight ticket," he smiled.



Vargas was thrilled to hear the pope speak about the importance of families on Saturday evening, about the importance of persevering in marriage through hard times.



"I come from divorced parents," Vargas said, looking over at Diaz, "His parents, too."



The couple has been married since 2009 and they go to church two to three times a week. – Saranac Hale Spencer

3:28 p.m.

3:27 p.m.

Several of the faithful stood on a Franklin Institute wall waiting for Pope Francis to give a second pass on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway on his way to say mass. Many shouted excitedly as the pope mobile repeatedly stopped so Francis could kiss young children. -- Esteban Parra

3:08 p.m.

2:50 p.m.

Pope Francis is preparing to depart a suburban Philadelphia seminary to make his way via a closed motorcade to the final act on his historic first trip to the United States.

Before celebrating an outdoor Mass on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Francis is scheduled to stop at Saint Joseph's University to bless a new statue honoring the relationship between Catholics and Jews.

He will then travel downtown and transfer to the popemobile for a procession along the parkway to the altar in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

Up to a million people or more are expected to crowd into the area for the Mass, and many reported waiting for hours to pass through security checkpoints.

Earlier Sunday, he visited the largest jail in Philadelphia to speak with inmates and their families. – Associated Press

2:44 p.m.

The Bible says a lot about patience. Security lines are testing the patience of pilgrims in Philadelphia. Check out our story:

2:35 p.m.

A group of 79 pilgrims from Vancouver, who are staying at St. John the Apostle Church in Milford, arrived in Philadelphia on Sunday afternoon for the pope's Mass on the parkway to find that the security lines to get in were too long.

Instead, they'll watch the Mass on a jumbotron set up on Broad Street, a few blocks south of City Hall.

It's OK, said Father Vittorio Scomparin, "it's exactly what I was expecting."

The crowd is expected to top one million for the Mass on Sunday afternoon. -- Saranac Hale Spencer

2:32 p.m.

Mike and Barbara Kaiser of Philadelphia stayed away from the papal events on Saturday, scared off by warnings that travel and security restrictions would make it difficult to get around.

Then they watched the television coverage and decided they had to come.

"We were crying, it was so beautiful," Mike said. "We looked at each other and said we have to go."

They said it was a breeze getting into the city by train Sunday.

"We grew up, live in and work in this city and we're so happy that people have been true to it. There's been real brotherly love," Barbara said.

The draw of the pope was so powerful that Mike said he was willing to miss watching the Philadelphia Eagles, the city's favorite sports team.

"We can see them any Sunday," he said. – Associated Press

2:21 p.m.

Maggie Fassano is a junior at the University of Delaware. But instead of spending her Sunday nights partying, she uses the pulpit at St. Thomas' to send a message about her religion.

"I think our campus is lacking in places of prayer," said Fassano, an early childhood education major. "Most people I talk to express the fact that they were born into a religion, but they don't really practice it anymore."

Fassano believes that if the University had more places of prayer, ways to educate and promote practices then people would be more involved with their religion.

"Some people just go on high holidays," said Fassano, who came to see the pope with her little sister, Brynn, 9. "With my religion, Catholic, we call these people 'creasters' and they are the people who only go to mass Christmas and Easter." -- Shannon Hawley

2:16 p.m.

2:15 p.m.

Delawarean Cathy Lozes is awaiting the Mass with Pope Francis along Benjamin Franklin Parkway in Philadelphia. Though pilgrims are packed arm-to-arm, Lozes said the mood is jubilant with singing and prayer.

"There are people here from all over the place. It is interesting and inspiring the kindness and patience everyone has for each other," Lozes said. "It is a nice vibe. People really seem excited when anything goes by. The jump up hoping it is the pope."

Lozes and her husband, John, are attending the Mass with two busloads of pilgrims from the Wilmington Society of St. Vincent DePaul. -- Xerxes Wilson

2:02 p.m.

Where large crowds are gathered, enterprising salesmen are sure to follow. That's no different for Pope Francis's visit to Philadelphia where David Thomas, of New Haven, Conn., sells flags to papal visitors making their way toward Benjamin Franklin Parkway Sunday.

2:05 p.m.

Pope Francis met Sunday with a family who made a 13,000-mile trip over 194 days from Argentina to Philadelphia in an old Volkswagen van.

Francis spent time with fellow Argentinians Catire Walker and Noel Zemborain and their four children and was touched by their experience, said Vatican spokesman Father Federico Lombardi.

Walker and Zemborain quit their jobs in food service and marketing to lead their children on the unforgettable tour of the Americas, using savings and soliciting donations to fund the trip to the World Meeting of Families in Philadelphia.

Along the way they made 12 border crossings and stayed with dozens of host families, did lots of sightseeing and documented the trip online. They schooled their children — Cala, 12; Dimas, 8; Mia, 5; and Carmin, 3 — with the help of a distance learning program.

"I think this kind of meeting shares the same spirit we want our journey to have — to meet other families, to know other families," Zemborain told The Associated Press last week. "The (World Meeting) slogan is 'The Family Fully Alive,' and that's how we feel as a family."

Zemborain, Walker and the kids plan to continue traveling until November.

Francis was to celebrate a Mass on Sunday that organizers estimated would draw more than 1 million people to downtown Philadelphia. — Associated Press

1:52 p.m.

Lily Loyola, of Mexico, waves an Our Lady of Guadalupe flag while making her way down Spring Garden Street toward the Benjamin Franklin Parkway to hear Pope Francis speak Sunday. Yesterday, Pope Francis, speaking entirely in his native Spanish at Independence Hall, told recent immigrants to celebrate the traditions of their native cultures. Catch up on Saranac Hale Spencer's coverage and video of Pope Francis's Saturday address at Independence Hall.

1:48 p.m.

1:42 p.m.

1:35 p.m.

Pilgrims are reporting security lines for the Mass to be celebrated with Pope Francis are taking more than an hour to get through. About 1 million people are expected to attend the mass.

"For me, it's a job of patience. I though it (security lines) would be a little quicker," said Ray Federici of West Chester, Pa.

A friend of Federici's accessed the Ben Franklin Parkway by walking around the blocked off areas and entering on Callowhill St. where his friend said the security lines are much shorter than on the Market St. side.

"Would have been nice to know you could get in another way quicker," Federici said. -- Meghan Montemurro

1:29 p.m.

Philadelphia city officials have stated the tent blocking the view of thousands lined up along Benjamin Franklin Parkway will be removed. The thousands already gathered for the 4 p.m. Mass were chanting for the tent to be removed as it blocks their view of the pope.

1:23 p.m.

It was barely noon in Love Park and David Isaacson had already sold 29 coins commemorating Pope Francis's visit. Pretty good for a third-grader.

"My buddy is the one that made all of the coins for today," said Danny Isaacson, 46, David's father. "I'm in construction."

Police have asked to see the Philadelphia duo's license to sell merchandise three times in the last two hours. But overall, they were doing pretty well.

"It's because I'm a great salesman," David says. "And because everyone thinks I'm cute." -- Kristine Iannelli

1:15 p.m.

Pope Francis will visit a sculpture dedicated to the 50th anniversary of a document calling for a strong relationship between Catholics and Jews.

Vatican spokesman the Rev. Federico Lombardi said Francis will see the sculpture commemorating the Nostra Aetate at Saint Joseph's University on his way back to the city before celebrating Mass in front of a massive crowd Sunday afternoon.

The sculpture was unveiled on Friday at a ceremony that included an address from Rabbi Abraham Skorka. Skorka is a longtime friend of the pope and Argentina's most famous rabbi.

The "Synagoga and Ecclesia in Our Time" statue was created by Philadelphia-based sculptor Joshua Koffman. – Associated Press

1:08 p.m.

As crowds of people in sneakers and backpacks head toward the parkway for the papal mass, the people who live on the streets of Philadelphia are sitting in their normal perches, crumpled cardboard signs in hand and coin cups at their feet.

One of them is 34-year-old John Scott, who grew up in south Jersey and worked as an auto mechanic until he got addicted to heroin two years ago.

Within six months, he lost his job, his apartment, and his car.

"Been out here ever since," Scott said.

Drug addiction is a sickness, "it really is," he said.

People "think they can hide it and live a normal life," he said, but they can't.

He used to get frustrated with his brother who struggled with heroin addiction for 10 years and would stay with him at times. Now he sees the struggle through the addict's eyes and it looks much different.

The crowd that's been here for the pope's visit has been nice, he said, and generous.

"They're all poped up," said Scott, who was wearing a white rosary around his neck sitting against a light post on Walnut Street.

Pope Francis is "really down to earth - in touch with the people, in touch with humanity," Scott said.

He likes that the pontiff takes on issues that are larger than just religion, like climate change - Scott called it a 360-degree view.

And, on poverty, Scott said, "he cares about that because it's wrong."

Then he paused, "it's not wrong," he said, casting his eyes down the street and thinking for a moment. "We're not handling it right," he said. -- Saranac Hale Spencer

1:00 p.m.

A crowd of hundreds are being directed around City Hall and toward a security check point on Callowhill Street. Among them is Jennifer Smith, from Indianapolis. She arrived in the Philadelphia area on Friday after a 12 hour drive with two friends in a truck and camper.

But they didn't head right to the city. Instead, they spent Saturday "sinning" in Atlantic City, she said.

"We went to the Tropicana, then we saw the ocean, then we went to Caesars palace," Smith said.

She suspects that other Catholics were likely also skipping Saturday papal events at those casinos. But seeing pope Francis give Mass today should be a sufficient way to repent, she said.

"He's very forgiving," she said.

2:57 p.m.

Mike Dejos and his wife Nhu Dao have taken advantage of their recent move to Chadds Ford, Pa.

The couple, who were with his sister Cheryl and her roommate Meghan Durkin, attended Pope Francis' speech at Independence Hall on Saturday and returned Sunday for Mass.

"It's such a blessing to be with other believers and who love the church," said Mike Dejos. "We all come from different backgrounds."

Mike Dejos, who works at DuPont, attended Thursday's Asian Catholic Mass at Our Lady of Hope in Northeast Philadelphia, which he called an awesome experience.

Sunday's extremely long lines to go through the security checkpoints -- Mike Dejos said his group was averaging only six steps every 15 minutes -- created a lot of waiting time. But it didn't ruin the experience for Dejos, who described his trip to Philadelphia as eye opening. -- Meghan Montemurro

12:47 p.m.

Volunteer Melanie Hurst, who is situated on the parkway as a volunteer, said a large, white tent that was recently set up near the stage is blocking the view of attendees and they're not happy about it.

Hurst said people are chanting and yelling to move the tent. -- Brittany Horn

12:37 p.m.

Pope Francis’ comments to bishops Sunday promising to hold those responsible for clergy sex abuse was a “clear call, one of accountability,” the chairman of the U.S. bishops committee charged with handling the issue said.

Bishop Edward Burns, of the Diocese of Juneau, told media members during a briefing that the church acknowledges that “the sacred has been twisted.” Burns is chairman of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops Committee for the Protection of Children and Young People.

The pope during a meeting with 300 bishops and others at the St. Charles Borromeo seminary Sunday morning says he promised to "zealously" protect young people and that "all those responsible are held accountable."

He also met at the seminary earlier Sunday with three women and two men who were abused as minors. The Rev. Federico Lombardi, a Vatican spokesman, said the pope prayed with the survivors, listened to their stories and expressed his closeness in their suffering and his "pain and shame" in the case of those abused by priests.

Pope Francis also has agreed to create a new Vatican tribunal to prosecute bishops who failed to protect, and he has accepted the resignations of three U.S. bishops accused of mishandling cases.

12:26 p.m.

12:19 p.m.

The Kirks, parishioners of St. Margaret's of Scotland in Newark, couldn't pass up the opportunity to head up to Philadelphia for Sunday's 4 p.m. Mass with Pope Francis.

Dan and Suzanne Kirk brought their four children -- Nicole, a sophomore at St. Mark's, Maureen, an eighth grader at Christ the Teacher where her twin brothers Josh and Sean also attend in sixth grade -- to Philadelphia and were joined by Suzanne's sister as well as a sister-in-law and her boyfriend. They were able to get tickets to the Mass through the church Suzanne's sister-in-law attends.

"Pope Francis is awesome," Nicole Kirk said.

The Kirks took a 10:30 a.m. train into the city and were part of a massive crowd of people trapped in long lines to go through security checkpoints.

"Just the experience of being near the Pope," Suzanne Kirk said. "I think it's important for [my kids]. They might not have another opportunity." -- Meghan Montemurro

11:55 a.m.

11:43 a.m.

Twenty-eight members from the Catholic Diocese of Wilmington will sing in the 500-member papal choir during the 4 p.m. Mass on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway, where large crowds already are gathering.

Michael Lundy is director of music and organist at St. Mary of the Assumption in Hockessin, where Patricia also sings in the choir.

"Right now everything is low key because we're just hanging out. Once the music starts, the excitement will really build up," Michael Lundy said from Philadelphia, where choir members are awaiting a 12:30 p.m. sound check.

"So many people are gathered around," he said. "It looks like a rock concert." – Jonathan Starkey

Check out Estaban Parra's story about the group preparing for the big day here and video of their preparations below.

11:34 a.m.

Pope Francis has invoked the parable of Jesus washing the feet of his apostles as he encouraged a group of prisoners to use their time in jail to get their lives back on track.

Francis said at Philadelphia's largest jail on Sunday that everyone is part of the effort to help the inmates rejoin society.

He has criticized prison systems that only work to punish and humiliate prisoners, and he has denounced life prison terms and isolation as a form of torture.

Francis spoke to the men and women in blue uniforms from in front of a special wooden chair made by inmates.

He said the journey of life means getting dirty feet and that everyone needs to be cleansed.

The Mass for the conclusion of the World Meeting of Families on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway is scheduled at 4 p.m. — Associated Press

11:24 a.m.

Security lines are long and getting longer as people gather on Benjamin Franklin Parkway where Pope Francis will celebrate Mass later this evening.

11:14 a.m.

SEPTA's new General Manager Jeff Knueppel said that, unlike the pope, he's not a miracle worker.

Trains mostly ran smoothly Saturday, but some people did have to wait for an hour or more to get home once the concert ended."It's funny because people don't understand that we couldn't condense four or five hours of trip time picking people up into one or 2 hours going home as easily," Knueppel said.

He compared the effects of the papal mass to a natural disaster like a snowstorm or an earthquake.

"I've never seen anything like this in terms of planning," he said."Normally, things that affect us hit one line or one mode -this hit everywhere."

The only thing similar was the 2008 Phillies World Series parade, and this was way bigger.

After riding the trains around himself yesterday, Knueppel says he has figured out part of the problem. On Saturday, they planned trains evenly across the whole system, but looking at the ridership, they made sure the heavier lines got more trains on Sunday.

There are police officers on every train and he'd be confident in putting the Pope on one of his SEPTA trains.

"And knowing this pope - he'd be up for it," he said. -- Madison Goebel

11:01 a.m.

With hours-long waits for a brief chance to catch a glimpse of Pope Francis, picking the right spot along the parkway is crucial. University of Delaware student Madison Ciccaglione describes how she found her post.

10:51 a.m.

Pope Francis is speaking to inmates at Curran-Fromhold Correctional Center through a translator.

The pontiff is standing on a raised platform, with a wooden chair made by inmates behind him. Inmates, wearing blue uniforms, sit in rows in front of the pope.

“I am here as a pastor, but above all, as a brother,” he said.

He also spoke about Jesus washing the feet of his disciples and the importance of rehabilitation.

“All of us have something we need cleansed of or purified from,” he said.

“Let us look to Jesus who washes our feet,” the pope said later.

10:32 a.m.

Pope Francis has arrived at Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility.

Francis is meeting with 100 inmates in the gym and his remarks will be broadcast to the other 3,000 inmates.

10:22 a.m.

10:20 a.m.

Large crowds are already in place on Benjamin Franklin Parkway to celebrate Mass with Pope Francis at 4 p.m. These University of North Carolina students play a game of Catchphrase to pass the time. -- Meghan Montemurro

10:12 a.m.

From across the country and around the world faithful Catholics are gathering for the final day of Pope Francis' first visit to the United States.

Pilgrims are packing subway cars and lugging bags and portable chairs as they make their way to Philadelphia's Benjamin Franklin Parkway, where Francis will celebrate an afternoon Mass that could draw a million people or more.

Before the Mass, Francis is scheduled to visit a Philadelphia prison where he will speak with inmates, members of their families and corrections officers.

10:07 a.m.

Pope Francis is on board a helicopter flying from St. Charles Borromeo Seminary to the Curran-Fromhold Correctional Center, where he’ll talk with inmates and families.

Inmates also made the pontiff a special wooden chair in which he will sit during the meeting.

The 25-acre facility opened in 1995 and is the largest in the Philadelphia Prison System. It is named Warden Patrick Curran and Deputy Warden Robert Fromhold, who were killed at Philadelphia’s Holmesburg prison in the line of duty in 1973.

The facility processes nearly 30,000 men a year.

9:58 a.m.

Pope Francis has departed the St. Charles Borromeo Seminary in Lower Merion, Pennsylvania after addressing a congregation of 300 bishops on the importance of marriage and other topics.

Yesterday the pope spoke on the importance of equality and the value of differing cultures at Independence Hall. Catch up on Saranac Hale Spencer's coverage and video of Pope Francis's Saturday address at Independence Hall.

9:51 a.m.

On his final day in the U.S., Pope Francis has lamented the legalization of gay marriage, but he also urged America's bishops to redirect their energies away from complaining.

He told 300 bishops at a seminary outside Philadelphia that a church that only explains its doctrine is "dangerously unbalanced."

The U.S. bishops have repeatedly decried the acceptance of same-sex relationships, calling the legalization of gay marriage by the U.S. Supreme Court three months ago "a tragic error" and a "profoundly immoral and unjust" decision.

Francis also decried a world in which people are always chasing the latest trend and treat matters of faith and relationships as if they were mere products in a supermarket

Leaving, he met with bishops and stood with seminarians who sang, snapped photos and cheered.

He is scheduled to meet with 100 inmates at Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility later Sunday. He was expected to offer them words of hope, forgiveness and redemption. — Associated Press

9:47 a.m.

9:45 a.m.

9:33 a.m.

Pope Francis is discussing consumerism and the importance of marriage during an address to bishops.

The pope, in a lighthearted moment, said he is sometimes approached by mothers wondering how they can encourage their sons to get married.

“Don’t iron his shirts anymore,” Pope Francis said, to laughter from those gathered.

The pope also met with survivors of church sex abuse. Francis has created a Vatican tribunal to address church leaders who don’t properly respond to sex abuse.

The pontiff will travel to a prison in Philadelphia later Sunday morning.

9:25 a.m.

For volunteers like Melanie Hurst, the papal visit has made for long days but the Delaware woman is already back at it this morning.

Hurst spent most of her Saturday working on the parkway and already has a spot for Sunday’s Mass slated to begin after 4 p.m. She’s staked out at the Oval along the parkway with the main stage not far off in the distance, where crowds are already beginning to pack the streets.

Hurst said the atmosphere is picking up despite the early morning wake-up call. Many volunteers and attendees didn’t crawl into bed until late Saturday due to the day full of festivities and the late-night performances at the Festival of Families.

“Crowds are still forming,” Hurst said. “Energy and volunteers here with me are great.” — Brittany Horn

9:15 a.m.

Pope Francis told bishops and others during a service at St. Charles Borromeo Seminary that “God weeps for the sexual abuse of children.”

The Philadelphia Archdiocese was the center of a sex abuse scandal. Former Philadelphia Cardinal Justin Rigali retired to the Diocese of Knoxville, Tennessee, months after a grand jury accused the Philadelphia archdiocese of sheltering more than three dozen credibly accused priests and lying about it to victims and others.

Francis on Sunday said abuse of children violated “trust and caused great pain.”

He said: “These cannot be maintained in secret and I commit to a careful oversight to ensure that youth are protected and that all responsible will be held accountable.”

9:06 a.m.

Francis is speaking to about 300 bishops and others Sunday in a chapel at the St. Charles Borromeo Seminary in Lower Merion, Pennsylvania.

Crowds cheered as the pontiff entered the church, walking down a central aisle with chandeliers overhead. He shook several hands in the front row, pausing briefly to speak to cardinals.

The pope stayed the night at the seminary after spending Saturday in Philadelphia on the final weekend of his trip to the U.S.

Pope John Paul II visited the seminary in 1979. It has also welcomed Mother Teresa and three cardinals who later became pope, including Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, who became Pope Benedict XVI. — Associated Press

9:02 a.m.

Mark Heinmiller knew he couldn't miss out on seeing Pope Francis in person.

Mark, his wife Julie along with his brother Bill and sister-in-law Ann made the journey from Columbus, Ohio to be part of Sunday's experience. Mark Heinmiller saw Pope John Paul II with his brother in St. Louis as well as Pope Benedict in Washington, D.C.

The Heinmillers took a 6 a.m. train in from Bensalem, PA, and Mark Heinmiller was surprised it wasn't too crowded. They were excited to grab a front row spot on the Ben Franklin Parkway where the Pope is expected to parade through this afternoon.

"Today has been fantastic so far," Mark Heinmiller said. "Our faith motivated us to come to Philadelphia for this opportunity." — Meghan Montemurro

8:51 a.m.

A large crowd is already in place for this evening's papal Mass on Benjamin Franklin Parkway. Pope Francis is scheduled to celebrate Mass on the parkway to conclude the World Meeting of Families at 4 p.m.

8:46 a.m.

Father Lopez Delfino is visiting Delaware as part of an exchange between Elizabeth Ann Seton and his church in San Marcos, Guatemala, and to reconnect with former members of his congregation who now live in Georgetown, he said.

When Delfino planned the trip to the U.S earlier in the year, he didn't know that St. Elizabeth would make the journey to see Pope Francis, he said.

"I thought I would just visit Georgetown and this parish," he said. "But I said,OK, let's go." — Karl Baker

8:24 a.m.

About 170 people are travelling from St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church in Bear to celebrate Mass with the pope this evening.

8:17 a.m.

The Delaware Department of Transportation is reporting no delays heading into Philadelphia.

Several highways in Pennsylvania are closed to vehicles of because the papal visit, including Interstate 76 westbound from Interstate 95 to U.S. 1, I-76 eastbound from Interstate 476 to I-95, the Ben Franklin Bridge in both directions, Interstate 676 in both directions and U.S. 1 in both directions from U.S. 30 to Belmont Avenue.

In New Jersey, I-676 northbound from Morgan Street to the Ben Franklin Bridge and U.S. 30 westbound from Airport Circle to the Ben Franklin Bridge are closed.

DelDOT is advising those traveling north of Philadelphia to use I-295 or the New Jersey Turnpike.

7:47 a.m.

Daniel Keiser, a University of Delaware senior from Newark, is catching up on some class reading while he and other students wait in Aviator Park for the pope's afternoon Mass. -- Estaban Parra

7:46 a.m.

Following a marathon day that started in New York City, Pope Francis woke up Sunday at St. Charles Borromeo Seminary in Lower Merion Township, Pennsylvania.

On Saturday, the 78-year-old pontiff arrived in Philadelphia and celebrated Mass, gave a speech on religious freedom at Independence Hall and attended a concert on the stage of the World Meeting of Families on Ben Franklin Parkway.

Before leaving the concert, Francis asked everyone to attend Mass Sunday. More than 1 million people are expected.

“Thank you,” the pope said. “See you tomorrow.”

The pope also painted the final stroke on a mural that will hang in Philadelphia in honor of the World Meeting of Families.

The pontiff’s schedule today is:

9:15 a.m.: Meeting with bishops at St. Martin's Chapel, St. Charles Borromeo Seminary

11 a.m.: Visit to Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility

4 p.m.: Mass for the conclusion of the World Meeting of Families, Benjamin Franklin Parkway

7 p.m. Visit with organizers, volunteers and benefactors of the World Meeting of Families, Atlantic Aviation

8 p.m. Departure for Rome

7:44 a.m.

Maddy Kilburn and Kaitlyn Quinn, freshmen at the University of Delaware, were happy to sacrifice a night out for an early departure to see the pope.

"At first I was a little apprehensive cause people pin you as that religious kid that doesn't have a good time, but it's really not like that," said Kilburn.

Kilburn and Quinn are two of 240 UD students to travel by bus to get front row viewing of the popes entrance for his 4 p.m. mass.

7:42 a.m.

Greeted by throngs of cheering faithful at every turn, Pope Francis is capping his whirlwind visit to the United States in an entirely fitting way — Mass for the masses on Philadelphia's grandest boulevard — while also spending time with inmates at its largest jail.

The 78-year-old "people's pope," who seems to feed off the energy of the crowds, is expected to see the largest of his six-day tour on Sunday when he celebrates a climactic outdoor Mass on the Benjamin Franklin Parkway before flying back to Rome.

The Mass is the culminating event of a Vatican-sponsored conference on the family that drew the wildly popular pontiff to Philadelphia.

He'll begin his day by speaking to bishops from around the world before heading to Curran-Fromhold Correctional Facility, where he'll visit with 100 inmates — a cross-section of suspected killers, rapists, mobsters. He's expected to offer them words of hope, forgiveness and redemption.

"His mission is the marginalized, the forgotten," prison spokeswoman Shawn Hawes said. "From our understanding, he wants those who are in custody to know that they are not forgotten and they can be redeemed." — Associated Press

7:34 a.m.

Just like Saturday, the residential areas of Rittenhouse surrounding Center City are quiet this morning with limited foot traffic heading towards the Ben Franklin Parkway. Members of the National Guard continue to be stationed along every block on 22nd Street and around Rittenhouse Park. — Meghan Montemurro

7:09 a.m.

Madison Ciccaglione, a University of Delaware freshman, has a little fun in Philadelphia's LOVE Park before she continues to the Ben Franklin Parkway to wait for Pope Francis' Mass at 4 p.m.

6:41 a.m.

Scott McDerby and his family are on the first SEPTA train from Wilmington to Philadelphia Sunday morning.

He boarded the train with wife Kristen and children Mackenzie and Matthew to join crowds on Pope Francis' second day in the city.

SEPTA said it sold just 60,000 passes for special commuter trains to the outdoor Mass - about 115,000 fewer than expected. About 1,100 buses have registered to bring people to papal events. Organizers had predicted 5,000 buses would sign up.

A vehicle ban around the sites of Francis' major events will remain in effect through the weekend.

.

Pennsylvania Army National Guard are on every block of South Broad Street as Joan Fassano of Pike Creek walks with her daughter Bridget Fassano, a UD sophomore, and her friend, Amanda Clarke, also a UD sophomore on their way to Benjamin Franklin Parkway. The women are part of more than 240 people coming from UD's St. Thomas More Oratory to listen to Pope Francis' Mass. — Esteban Parra

More than 50 riders boarded SEPTA's first train from Wilmington Sunday morning, hoping to catch a glimpse of Pope Francis during his second day in Philadelphia. Mike Bellina of Tinton Falls Township, N.J., said he drove about an hour to Wilmington on Saturday night with wife Amy and son Mike to be sure they made the connection. "I'm hoping to at least get a good picture," Mike Bellina said. "After that it will be all gravy." search_result.title: When is Ramadan in 2024? Plus, why it's celebrated, holiday ...
search_result.text:
Ramadan is less than a month away.

Before the holiday commences, we have put together a refresher to help you understand what Ramadan is, why it is celebrated and more.

What is Ramadan?

Ramadan is one of the holiest months of the year for Muslims.

During the monthlong holiday, Muslims commemorate the revelation of the Quran (the holy book of Islam) when Allah, through the angel Gabriel, revealed the first verses of the Quran to a caravan trader named "Muhammad," according to Almanac.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Ramadan is also a time for fasting from drinking or eating during sunlight hours to draw closer to God and cultivate self-control, gratitude, and compassion for the less fortunate, according to ING.

When is Ramadan in 2024?

Although Ramadan is always the ninth month of the Islamic calendar, the exact dates of the holiday change each year because they are based on the sighting of the first crescent moon over Mecca, Saudi Arabia, on the last night of the eighth month, Sha’ban. Some choose to observe Ramadan by following pre-determined dates based on astronomical calculations, reports Almanac.

In 2024, Ramadan starts at sundown on Sunday, March 10, and ends at sundown on Tuesday, April 9.

The last evening of Ramadan is Eid al-Fitr (Festival of Breaking the Fast), which is celebrated during the first three days of Shawwal, the 10th month in the Islamic calendar, according to the Pluralism Project.

Eid al-Fitr does not begin until the new moon is seen, which means it starts at different times around the world. Some Muslims choose to celebrate when the new moon appears over Mecca. During Eid al-Fitr, the monthlong fast for Ramadan officially ends and is celebrated with a feast.

How is Ramadan celebrated?

Ramadan is a period of spiritual rejuvenation, focusing heavily on devotion. During the month, Muslims perform special prayers and spend extra time reading the Quran, along with fasting.

The fast is from pre-dawn to sunset each day, lasting between 11 and 16 hours for 29 to 30 days, depending on the time of year. Muslims fast from food and drink; abstain from sex, if married; and refrain from negative acts such as lying, gossiping, arguing or backbiting, according to ING.

The goal of fasting is to gain “greater God-consciousness,” known in Arabic as “taqwa,” signifying a state of constant awareness of God. This awareness allows a person to gain self-restraint, discipline and a greater incentive to avoid wrong and do good.

All post-pubescent Muslims are obligated to fast except those with exemptions, including someone who is pregnant or nursing, children, sick individuals and elderly people. Sick people can make up the fast when they feel better and can instead feed a poor person for every day of fasting that they miss. Children around age 7 can perform limited or symbolic fasts, such as fasting for half a day or on weekends.

Due to fasting, the holiday is a highly social time and often sees the community inviting one another over for breakfast and meeting up for prayers at the mosque.

Sehri, or suhri, is the pre-dawn meal families eat together every morning, followed by a morning prayer. At night, Muslims break their fast with a meal known as “iftar,” which is traditionally started by eating dates like the Prophet Muhammad is believed to have done to break his fast. Iftar is often shared with a poor family, according to Almanac.

A special part of Ramadan is the Night of Power, known as Lailat al-Qadr, that is believed to fall on one of the odd nights during the last 10 days of Ramadan but is widely observed on the 27th night. It is seen as the most blessed night in Ramadan because it is said to be the night the Quran was first revealed, according to Britannica.

Mosques are open all night on the Night of Power as Muslims hold vigils in contemplation, prayer and Quranic recitation.

Once Eid al-Fitr arrives, the last day of Ramadan, Muslims enjoy great feasts and celebrate with the community.

Ramadan traditions

It is customary for Muslims to attempt to read the entire Quran during Ramadan and have it recited during special nightly prayers, according to ING.

During the nightly meal, mosques are known to host community dinners to foster relationships and offer a break from cooking to those fixing up iftar at home. Afterward, special Ramadan prayers called "Taraweeh" are held and 1/30 of the Quran is recited to ensure the full text is read by the end of the holiday. With charity being an element of the holiday, mosques often hold fundraisers or food drives during Ramadan, and even invite community members from other faiths inside to enjoy iftar.

During Eid al-Fitr, it is a tradition for children to receive money, gifts or new clothes from loved ones.

The first day of the celebration begins with a special prayer and sermon in the morning, followed by a celebration with the community filled with food and games. Families also visit the graves of relatives, according to Britannica.

How to greet someone during Ramadan

There are many ways to greet someone during Ramadan or express you well wishes for the holiday.

“Ramadan Mubarak” means “blessed Ramadan” and can be said to those observing the holiday, according to Almanac.

Similarly, “Eid Mubarak” means “blessed holiday,” and can be used to greet someone on during Eid al-Fitr, according to ING.

Other ways to greet someone during Ramadan, according to Parade, include:

“Sending wishes for a peaceful Ramadan.”

“Wishing you a happy Ramadan.”

“May Ramadan bring you prosperity and joy.”

“Sending love to you and your family this Ramadan.”

“May all your prayers be answered this Ramadan and always.”
