search_result.title: Johnson City's Diane Busko helped a festival, Catholic parish grow
search_result.text:
Just before the kids go back to school every year, thousands of people meet at Northside Park in Johnson City to celebrate the unofficial end of summer at the Johnson City Field Days.

Children ride carnival carousels or try their hand at one of the game booths while adults munch on their fried favorites and visit the many booths set up as fundraisers for local nonprofit organizations.

At the heart of it all was Diane (Salva) Busko.

As co-chair of the Johnson City Celebration Committee, Diane worked behind the scenes bringing entertainment acts to the festival each year, adding a parachute team from West Point in 2017 and sending out informative media releases leading up to the event.

She was a kindhearted woman who had an infectious smile, as well as a deep devotion to her Catholic faith, and she simply got things done.

Diane (Salva) Busko, 45, of Johnson City, died May 3, according to her obituary.

How CatholicMatch brought them together

Diane's leadership at the Field Days and in her passion for her job at the Village of Johnson City are prime examples of his wife's personality, Nik Busko says, but what first drew the two of them together was faith.

Nik and Diane met on CatholicMatch.com, a dating site for Catholic singles, on Valentine's Day in 2014. Their meeting was a fluke: Diane had tried a few other dating sites, including CatholicMatch, with no luck, but she reactivated her account on a whim.

Within the hour, she received a message from Nik.

It was a long-distance relationship at the start — he was a sports broadcaster for West Point Military Academy, a nearly three-hour drive from Johnson City, where she was deputy clerk.

A month after meeting online, Diane came down for a visit. She sat through a 15-3 baseball game while Nik worked and it was in that moment Nik says God decided their future.

"Suddenly God made the decision for me. He said, 'Pick Diane.'"

When the hockey season started, she met him on weekends for games whether they were in West Point or elsewhere across the state. In the summer, Nik volunteered during all four days of Johnson City Field Days.

Speaking for an article posted on CatholicMatch.com, Diane spoke of Nik's dedication, and calling the Field Days "her baby."

"He did not hesitate to jump right in and hep wherever he could," she said.

They were married Dec. 19, 2015, at the Church of the Holy Trinity in Binghamton, a young parish Diane helped build from three closed First Ward churches: St. Ann's, St. Joseph's and St. Stanislaus Kostka.

"No one can ignore the work Diane did with her church," Nik said. "It was the leadership she showed during a time of transition that drew me to her, and that leadership rubbed off on other people."

Building her church

Marie Lukasik met Diane for the first time when the three churches merged in 2003, ushering strong Slovak, Lithuanian and Polish backgrounds into the same worship space.

Marie and Diane were on the Liturgy and Worship committee formed to design that space at the site of the former St. Ann's on Prospect Street.

"She was always looking for creative ways to make our worship space warm, inviting and in tune with the liturgical seasons of the church," Marie said.

Never, perhaps, was that more evident than during the Christmas season — Nik said no one loved Christmas more than Diane — when a large, 12-foot tree, called the Unity Tree, was set up in the church's gathering area. Instead of having the tree decorated, the committee invited all parishioners to add their own ornaments, representative of their families and ethnicity.

On their wedding day, held just before Christmas, Nik and Diane took several pictures near the tree.

A year after the tree tradition began in 2004, in an article published in the Catholic Sun, Diane looked back on it.

"I think that's when it finally, truly jelled," she said at the time. "It was a moving time for everybody."

Diane's passion for her Catholic faith and her new parish demonstrated itself in many ways. She helped prepare a history of St. Ann's parish before the merger, Marie said, and after, she worked to do the same to chronicle the other formerly separate parishes.

She taught religious education for many years, helped prepare children to receive Holy Communion and served as parish council president.

"(She) helped our new parish grow and thrive," Marie said.

'We can handle it'

Diane's involvement in the Johnson City Field Days was similar. For the core group of organizers — only a handful of people — behind the four-day event, Diane's role was essential.

Former Johnson City mayor Harry Lewis, who is also on the Johnson City Celebration Committee, said Diane somehow managed to do the work of two people in planning the festival.

After a full day's work for the village, Diane would go home and start working on Field Days planning. She retrieved all the necessary permits and approvals, lined up entertainment acts and coordinated with the participating vendors and organizations.

It was a job in which Lewis said she had to be able to multi-task, jumping back and forth between different projects but still remembering where she'd left off.

"It's a monumental task and she handled it with ease," he said. "She put her whole heart and soul into that."

She did so with an infectious smile, Lewis said, and a personable attitude that made her easy to work with, no matter how stressful the situation. Even if something didn't look like it was going to turn out well, Diane had a way of easing the tension.

"She'd give you a little grin and say, 'We can handle it,'" Lewis said.

This year, when Labor Day rolls around, Northside Park in Johnson City is expected to once again fill with families attending the Johnson City Field Days, an event Diane called "a wonderful hometown celebration to celebrate our community and celebrate the end of summer," in a 2015 article published in the Press & Sun-Bulletin.

While Nik says his wife "never did anything for validation," her legacy lives in the young parish and the 51-year-old festival she helped to thrive.

Diane (Salva) Busko is survived by her husband, Nikolai Busko; mother, Virginia Salva; brother, Steve Salva; sister, Joanne Salva; grandmother, Arlene Karaim; aunt and uncle, Tom & Bernice Salva; and several cousins.

search_result.text:
CNN —

Australia’s largest music festival has turned into a mud pit, forcing organizers to cancel the first day of acts as concertgoers complained of quagmires and flooded tents.

Fans had been excited about the return of Splendour in the Grass, a three-day festival featuring international acts like Liam Gallagher, Gorillaz, Tyler The Creator and The Strokes, after a two-year pandemic-enforced hiatus.

But non-stop rainy weather along the New South Wales coast throughout the week has created hazardous conditions at the festival site near Byron Bay, the upmarket coastal town popular with Hollywood celebrities.

As they canceled Friday’s program, organizers said the “weather and staff shortages were all worse than expected.”

“A significant weather system is currently sitting off the east coast and may reach land later today bringing more rainfall,” organizers said in a statement published on the event’s Facebook page.

“In the interest of patron safety and in consultation with all relevant emergency services, we have decided to err on the side of caution and cancel performances on the main stages today only.”

The muddied festival grounds at Splendour in the Grass 2022 Marc Grimwade/WireImage/Getty Images

About 50,000 people were expected to attend this year’s festival, most of whom paid between A$189 ($130) for a single day pass and A$399 ($275) for three full days.

Pictures and videos posted on social media showed pooling muddy water and dozens of festival goers dressed in ponchos braving heavy rain. Many lamented the bad organization of the event, sharing their “nightmare experiences” on social media of dealing with snaking traffic jams and bogged vehicles as people tried to get into and out of the festival grounds.

One attendee, who said he’d been stuck in his car for 8.5 hours, likened the event to Australia’s “Fyre Festival” – an event touted as a five-star experience in the Bahamas in 2017 that offered little more than tents and bad sandwiches.

“No staff, no information, think this is Australia’s Fyre festival. A hell scape at Splendour,” he said.

Others called for the festival to be canceled in the interest of public safety. “I’m honestly of the opinion that if you put the safety of both staff and attendees first, then you should cancel,” said one Facebook user.

But the organizers vowed the show could would continue on Saturday and Sunday. “Please be assured that our event team is working very hard to provide the best experience possible under the current circumstances,” they said in a statement.

“We look forward to Saturday and Sunday programming moving ahead as planned.”

As much of the world has sweltered during summer heatwaves, Australia has experienced a particularly wet winter, punctuated by flooding along the eastern coast.

Experts the climate crisis had increased the frequency and intensity of the La Nina weather system, generating above average rainfall.

Devastating floods hit New South Wales, Australia’s most populous state, earlier this month, damaging homes still waiting repairs from the previous floods and forcing businesses to shutter.

Editors

USA TODAY

Georgia Gov. Kemp lifts many COVID-19 rules on businesses

In a new executive order that takes effect Saturday and runs through May 30, Georgia Republican Gov. Brian Kemp is removing many remaining requirements for social distancing and masked employees from businesses, saying the state's efforts to control COVID-19 have been successful. Kemp's order comes even as Georgia's vaccination rate lags and federal officials continue to warn that infection rates remain relatively high. "Too soon," Emory University infectious disease expert Carlos del Rio wrote on Twitter. "We still have 'substantial transmission' and our percent of population fully vaccinated is low." Over 6 million vaccine doses have been given in Georgia, but the state ranks 44th in doses administered per capita to people 18 and older. Data from Thursday shows 34% of Georgia residents with at least one dose and 25% fully vaccinated. Nationally, 43% of people have received at least one dose and 30% are fully vaccinated, the CDC reports.

Prefer to listen? Check out the 5 Things podcast:

Israel mourns victims of deadly stampede

A day of national mourning will be held Sunday after a tragic accident at a Jewish religious gathering attended by about 100,000 observants in northern Israel early Friday. According to witnesses and video, a large number of people started falling on top of one another in a narrow tunnel-like passage. The stampede killed at least 45 people, including four Americans, and injured many more. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called it "one of the worst disasters that has befallen the state of Israel."

Busy sports weekend: Kentucky Derby returns as the NFL draft wraps up

After the pandemic forced a spectator-less race last September, the Kentucky Derby returns to tradition and will be held the first Saturday of May. Post time for the race at the famous Churchill Downs track is 6:57 p.m. ET. Although the unbeaten Essential Quality is this year's favorite, columnist Dan Wolken writes that Highly Motivated has the skills to win. In Cleveland, the third and final day of the NFL draft will take place Saturday (noon ET, ABC, ESPN, NFL Network). After an action-packed first three rounds Thursday and Friday that saw surprises, trades and eight different teams select quarterbacks, plenty of talent remains available to pick up in rounds 4-7.

Kobe Bryant's daughter remembered on her birthday

A clothing line honoring Gianna Bryant launches Saturday, which would've been her 15th birthday. She died along with her father, NBA legend Kobe Bryant, and seven other people in a helicopter crash in Southern California last year. All proceeds from the clothing line will go to the Mamba and Mambacita Sports Foundation, which Vanessa Bryant launched after the death of her husband and daughter. Images of the pants online show a heart around Gigi Bryant's No. 2 jersey that she wore as part of her youth basketball team participation.

Kobe Bryant's widow names names in grisly photo case

in grisly photo case Vanessa Bryant wins case related to crash site photos

May marks the start of Mental Health Awareness Month

Mental Health Awareness Month kicks off Saturday and this past year has impacted everyone's mental health in different ways. One way to help yourself is by expressing gratitude regularly, which is why Lindsey Vickers of Reviewed.com gave gratitude journaling a shot by writing down things she was thankful for every night. "Nothing changed my sleep—and overall mood—as much as gratitude journaling. It took a week or so for me to see any effect, but after that the difference was practically palpable," she said. Two years after starting a conversation about mental health, rapper Big Sean continues to champion wellness and mental stability. On Saturday, he'll launch a weekly video series that will run at his foundation Instagram page and website throughout this month. The rapper will be joined by his mother, Myra Anderson, and they will discuss assorted topics and techniques, including meditation, diet, sleep rhythms and mindset.

Contributing: The Associated Press

search_result.title: 101 things to do in Montana
search_result.text:
Tribune Staff

Whether you live in Montana and are looking for a road trip, or visiting the state from afar, we have 101 outings for you to put on your bucket list.

IN AND AROUND GREAT FALLS

1 River's Edge Trail

As the Missouri River "meanders through Great Falls, sheltering waterfowl and encouraging other wildlife — and human recreation — along its banks," so does this nearly 60 miles of paved and graveled pathways for walking, running, skating and bicycling. A result of a cooperative partnership by the city of Great Falls, Cascade County, Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks, Department of Transportation, PPL Montana and the volunteer trail advocacy group, Recreational Trails Inc., it is one of the urban delights of Great Falls that blends the city with its rural surroundings. Some of its "splashy features include Black Eagle Falls, Rainbow Falls, Crooked Falls, Ryan Falls (the "great falls of the Missouri") and Morony Falls, outdoor art and memorial benches and tables and picnic shelters.

In 1990, Recreational Trails Inc. formed to help forge the riverside route, which grows each year with new places and trails to explore. The paved, wheelchair-accessible trail runs along the south shore of the river, from Oddfellows Park, which is near the Warden Bridge on 10th Avenue South, past Broadwater Bay, Mitchell Pool, Gibson and Elks Riverside Parks, Black Eagle Falls, the Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center, Giant Springs Heritage State Park and Rainbow Falls to the Crooked Falls Overlook. The asphalt ends there, but the trail doesn't. A dirt trail stretches along the cliffs another three miles to Cochrane Dam.

East of Great Falls, the North Shore Trail follows along Cochrane, Ryan and Morony reservoirs. The trail begins at the end of Rainbow Dam Road and includes gravel and single track segments totaling more than 13 miles. A single-track trail now runs between Rainbow and Morony dams, and a trailhead has been established at Rainbow Dam. An expert single-track trail between Ryan and Cochrane dams provides an exceptional way to explore the river canyon east of town. Interpretive signs describing the ecology of the area have been provided by the Cascade Conservation District and the Missouri River Council, and QR Code signs along the trail make information about the trail and dams available to smartphone users.

The Montana Department of Transportation has completed the design of the Sun River Connector Trail to extend a separated bike and pedestrian connection along Country Club Blvd., between the west approach of the Warden Bridge and 6th Street Southwest, and construction will begin in 2016. This summer's improvements will include a paved loop from Heritage Park down to Giant Springs, a new trail between the Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center and Giant Springs and the opening of a 2.1-mile loop linking the Heritage Center, Giant Springs and Heritage Park. Paving will be done to the parking area at Bay Drive, and United Materials will be redoing the shoulders along the trail from 15th Street to Giant Springs.

Summer 2015 activities include Audubon West Wednesday Walks for bird watching along the river and on Sacajawea Island, Cochrane Dam crossings on July 11 and Aug. 22 and a number of "fun runs" and mountain bike activities. For details call 788-3313 or read more about the trails at www.thetrail.org.

2 The C.M. Russell Museum

Visitors from all over the world enjoy the Great Falls museum named after the famous cowboy artist who adopted Great Falls as his home more than a century ago. They also can enjoy the Russell Rider Sculpture Garden, a place "families can come, free of charge, all four seasons" to picnic, roam the garden and appreciate wonderful art including five major bronze pieces. Five galleries have been installed to showcase the "astonishing depth and range" of Russell's art, which ranged from paintings and sculpture to illustrated letters and pen-and-ink drawings during his lifetime (1864-1926). The museum has some 2,000 Russell artworks, personal objects and a "permanent collection of more than 12,000 objects" including works of such well-known artists as O.C. Seltzer, Winold Reiss, J.H. Sharp and Frank Tenney Johnson.

Don't miss "The Bison: American Icon, Heart of the Plains Indian Culture," the most ambitious permanent exhibition ever displayed at the C.M. Russell Museum. With about 500 artifacts and a thundering buffalo diorama that shakes as you walk over it, the $1.5 million exhibition is a fitting subject because three-quarters of the Russell Museum's entire collection of paintings and sculpture involve Indians and bison. The "Browning Firearms Collection" of rifles, shotguns and handguns surveys the significant developments made by the Browning, Winchester and Colt companies. New this season is "Harmless Hunter: The Wildlife Work of Charles M. Russell," runs through Sept. 13, and "focuses for the first time on Russell's painting of wildlife."

Right beside the museum is Russell's Log Studio, built in 1903. The artifacts in it belonged to Russell and were used for reference in his artwork. The Russell home next door was built in 1900 under the supervision of his wife, Nancy. During the summer, the museum, located at 400 13th St. N., is open Tuesday to Sunday. Museum hours are 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., the cabin studio is open 10 a.m. to 4:45 p.m., and the home is open 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Admission is $9 for adults, $7 for seniors, retired military and schedule tour groups, $4 for students and is free for active military and kids under age 5. Call 727-8787, or visit www.cmrussell.org.

3 Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center

The Lewis and Clark Interpretive Center is nestled into the bluffs of the Missouri River overlooking a section of river where the famed explorers portaged two centuries ago to avoid the nearby waterfalls. Black Eagle Falls, the uppermost of the five falls, is visible from the big windows of the interpretive center. Outside, four pedestrian trails connect the interpretive center with Giant Springs Heritage State Park, and a bicycle-pedestrian trail connects the interpretive center with the River's Edge Trail via a tunnel beneath Giant Springs Road.

Inside the center, the exhibits are educational and interactive. The ground floor includes the ornate Compass Rose, with a list of private contributors who helped finance the original construction. Only half of the construction cost was funded with federal money. Pictographs tell the explorers' story in Indian drawings. Grabbing the most attention as visitors enter the center is a striking life-size diorama of buckskin-clad explorers hefting a 30-foot canoe up a ravine in their portage around the falls. The exhibit stretches two stories and is framed by vast windows overlooking the Missouri.

The center "imparts to the public a personal sense of President Thomas Jefferson's vision of expanding America to the west; it inspires awe and awakens curiosity toward the challenges faced by the expedition as they portaged the great falls of the Missouri river and explored the 'unknown'; brings to life the daily experiences of the expedition and the environment and native peoples of the 'uncharted West'; and celebrated the indomitable spirit of human discovery we all share," according to the center's mission statement.

The 26th Annual Lewis and Clark Festival is taking place June 19-21 and promises to deliver participants "back to ways of the Lewis and Clark Expedition and life out on the open frontier of the West." This special event includes historical programs, children's activities, Native American cultural programs, artisans and local craftspeople and a variety of local food vendors.

On Fridays beginning June 26, "Riverside Voices," staff of the center and guest presenters, offer evening programs in the amphitheater on the bluffs overlooking the Missouri River or in the indoor theater. Topics include medicine on the expedition, the boats used in the journey, changes in the river since the exploration and more Lewis and Clark history and related subjects. A "Star Party Extravaganza" for learning about our night sky with the Central Montana Astronomy Society, is Sept. 25 in the center's parking lot.

Summer hours are 9 a.m.-6 p.m. daily. Costs are $8 for adults and free for those 15 and younger. Federal Interagency Annual, Senior, Military and Access Passes are honored for free entry.

Contact Information: 4201 Giant Springs Road, Great Falls, MT 59405. Phone: 406-727-8733.

4 Alive @ Five

If you enjoy live music, street dancing and great food, friends and fun, plan to attend Alive @ 5, a "big city experience in the heart of Great Falls." Every Thursday from June 11 through Aug. 6 (except for July 30), one designated area of downtown comes alive with "the finest street music tradition" of food vendors, liquid refreshments, live music and activities for children. The June 18 date was reserved for "Taste of Great Falls," a sampling of fare from local restaurants, and Aug. 6 also will be a fundraiser for Roberts Park. The events are held from 5 to 9 p.m. Call 406-453-6151 or visit downtowngreatfalls.net for more information.

5 Giant Springs State Park

First documented by the Lewis and Clark Expedition in 1805, Giant Springs is one of the largest freshwater springs in the world. This is also the site of the Roe River, once listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the world's shortest river. Giant Springs flows at a measured 7.9 million gallons per hour or 156 million gallons of water per day. The water stays at a temperature of 54 degrees and has been carbon dated to be about 3,000 years old. More than a quarter of a million lovers of nature visit Giant Springs Heritage Park each year. Many come to marvel at this remarkable feature, or to view the 80-plus species of birds, mammals and reptiles. On any day you may find bicyclists, fishing enthusiasts, photographers and many others; some come to visit the nearby Rainbow Falls Overlook, the visitor center and the fish hatchery.

The fish hatchery program raises from 700,000 to 800,000 fish annually. They are then distributed to areas in central Montana from the Canadian border to the Wyoming border. A group picnic site is also available. The Fish, Wildlife and Parks visitor center (right across from the roadway from the springs) features taxidermy mounts of grizzly and black bears, educational features on fish and bird recognition, wildlife photographs, and a mini-theater that shows wildlife videos. Pets on leash are welcome.

Events at the park include ranger talks dealing with the wildlife of the area, bird strolls and kids activities. Check the website at stateparks.mt.gov for specific dates. Concerts will be held in the park on July 12 and Aug.9, and visitors may want to plan to attend Movie Night in the Park on Aug. 21 or the Fall Family Fest on Oct. 17.

Located off U.S. Highway 87 in Great Falls, then a mile east on River Drive to Giant Springs Road. The park is open year-round from are 8 a.m. to sunset; the visitor center is open Monday to Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission is free for vehicles with Montana plates and $6 per vehicle for those from out-of-state.

6 Paris Gibson Square Museum of Art

One of Great Falls' oldest and most recognizable landmarks, the Square, at 1400 1st Ave. N., has served as a center for learning and growth for more than 100 years. Built of native gray sandstone, the structure was completed in 1896 and served for 34 years as a high school and for 45 years as a junior high. "Art is for everyone" is the premise of the Square; since 1977, it has provided a "dynamic program of exhibitions, classes, lectures, tours and performances designed to nurture the region's creative spirit."

The "Val Knight Retrospective," a new permanent exhibition has been added to the Square and includes 25 remarkable works done from the 1960s to the 1990s by the late Great Falls artist in a variety of media that includes encaustic paintings, ceramic figurines and graphic drawings. Other summer exhibitions include "The Blind Men & the Elephant: Drawings by Steven Glueckert" until Aug. 1; "Artist in Residence – Danielle O'Malley" until Sept. 1; "Alas, the Pelicans: Randi O'Brian" until Sept. 11; and Manel Alvares: A Journey" July 28-Oct. 16.

Home-style cooking with an international flair is the forté of Café Paris, which is open for two lunch services, at noon and 12:30 p.m., on Wednesdays and Thursdays of each week. Lunches are priced at $15. Reservations are required.

Admission is free as a gift to the community from Farmers Union Insurance. Open Monday to Friday, 10 a.m.-5 p.m., Tuesday, 5-9 p.m. and Saturday, noon-5 p.m. Closed Sundays, July 4 and Labor Day. Call 406-727-8255 or visit www.the-square.org.

7 The History Museum

"When you enter the History Museum, you walk back in time in North Central Montana!" promises the 47,000-square-foot museum at 4223 2nd St. S., in the old Northern School Supply building. Permanent exhibits on Cascade County and northcentral Montana are featured, and temporary exhibitions on topics ranging from Montana history to local art augment the collection. Current exhibits include a salute to the history of nursing at the Columbus Hospital from 1900 to 1968 and a new exhibit centered around the history of downtown Great Falls. Permanent exhibits include the Bovey carriage, models of the Opera House and Park Hotel and displays on the Ozark Club and Native Americans. As well as "Under the Big Stack: the Great Falls Smelter" about the Anaconda Copper Mining Company's history in Great Falls.

The Museum also houses the Archival Research Center on the second floor, a gift shop and space available for special events. Museum hours are Tuesday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., and by appointment on weekends. Admission is free with donations welcome. Call the History Museum at 452-3462 or visit www.thehistorymuseum.org.

8 Children's Museum of Montana

The Children's Museum is a wonderland where "please touch" is one of the most important rules. The museum, which turned 14 in February, is an educational and community resource "dedicated to the notion that children learn best by doing." Exhibits and programs focused on history and culture, science and technology, health and nutrition, visual and performing arts and regional culture offer a unique hands-on adventure.

Located at 22 Railroad Square, the museum is just northwest of the Civic Center and within a Frisbee flip of Gibson Park. Housed in the historical railroad district, the 1913 museum building originally was a food brokerage that unloaded supplies from railcars on the adjacent tracks.

Cost is $4 per person and free for children under 2; memberships are available starting at $65 a year. Groups of 10 or more are always welcome with 24 hours notice; the cost is $3 per child in the group, and one adult must accompany each five children. Call 452-6661 or visit www.childrensmuseumofmontana for current programs.

9 Other Great Falls Experiences

Great Falls boasts many other museums and art galleries that work well together as a group. They showcase local artists and an impressive array of the city's history and culture including:

The Great Falls Public Library houses the Great Falls Genealogy Society on the third floor. Since 1975, the society has encouraged an active interest in genealogy and preserving genealogical records that could help patrons learn about ancestors in this region. It's staffed entirely by volunteers. The library is open Tuesday to Saturday, 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Call 727-3922 or visit www.gfgenealogy.org.

The mission of Galerie Trinitas, located adjacent to the chapel on the University of Great Falls campus, is to preserve the art of Sister Trinitas Morin and to promote "an appreciation for religious art." A Sister of Providence, she "created art for the chapel, friends and for special occasions." Some of her pieces are currently in the traveling art show, "Women's Spirit, Catholic Sisters in America." Hours are noon-3 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday, or by appointment by calling 791-5367. Admission is free.

The Malmstrom Air Force Base Museum at the east end of 2nd Avenue North, has displays that depict the history of Malmstrom Air Force Base from its beginning as a B-17 training base to the largest Minuteman ICBM missile field in the world. Public passes are available at base visitor center at the 2nd Avenue North gate. The museum is free and open Monday-Friday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Call 731-2705 for additional/weekend hours, special arrangements or for more information or visit them online at www.malmstrom.af.mil/library/malmstrommuseum.index.asp.

The Ursuline Retreat and Conference Centre and Museum, located at 2300 Central Ave., has transformed from a solely educational institution to its present function as a retreat and meeting center and a museum of antiques and Indian artifacts while still providing learning experiences through a child care and pre-school. The building, placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1991, opened its doors in 1912, and the fourth floor archive preserves the documented history of the Ursuline Sisters in Montana and the western states. Hours are Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. with guided tours available by appointment. Call 452-8585 or visit www.u-centre.com.

Grab your camera, and hop on! The owners of the Great Falls Historic Trolley, the Downtown Great Falls Association, now offers tours of the scenic and historically and culturally rich Great Falls seven days a week beginning June 1 and ending Sept. 1. The "historic" two-hour tour is $22 for adults and $5 for children, and departs from Paris Gibson Square Monday to Saturday. at 10:30 a.m. The "Urban Adventure" one-hour tours are $15 for adults and run Friday to Sunday. at 1:30 p.m., and Monday to Saturday at 4:30 p.m. Choose a package tour or customize your very own by calling 727-8255. And for vacation information, tours and shuttles throughout central and northcentral Montana, contact Tour de Great Falls at 771-1100 or 888-707-1100.

On the first Friday of each month, downtown galleries, museums and businesses in Great Falls stay open late to welcome guests who can take a peek at area artists' latest works in the First Friday Art Walk. Guests often are treated to drinks, food and live music at the various sites. Check the Tribune's "Hot Ticket," published each Friday, for details about that week's participating artists.

10 Community Rec Center

The Rec Center offers summer camps, after-school programs, exercise rooms and dance classes, all in a safe environment. The center's amenities include kids' program room, meeting room, gym, running track, indoor golf range and a fitness center. Recreation programs include youth and adult sports leagues and after-school and summer vacation activities. Located at 801 2nd Ave. N., it's open year-round, Monday.-Thursday from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m., Friday 6 a.m.-7 p.m. and 9 a.m.-2 p.m. on Saturdays. Call 727-6099.

The Center also houses the nostalgically decorated Good Eats Cafe, open 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Monday through Friday, with traditional breakfast and lunch, as well as old-fashioned sodas and snacks. The café now also serves a variety of salads, wraps and homemade soups, including an award-winning chili. Call 452-0773.

11 Riverside Rail Yard Skate Park

Great Falls is the envy of skateboarders all across the Big Sky with its 27,000-square-foot Riverside Rail Yard that is "considered one of the top five skate parks in the Pacific Northwest." The park features a series of bowls, including one that's 9 feet deep, a fullpipe, halfpipes, a clamshell and a street course with ledges, rails and stairs. There also are handicapped-accessible restrooms, a plaza with picnic tables for spectators, a drop-off area and nearby parking. And the best part? The facility, which is open from dawn to dusk, is free for skateboarders, in-line skaters and roller skaters. The skaters' paradise is in Elks Riverside Park, 500 River Drive N., behind the Girl Scout cabin and near the Gibson Park underpass.

12 Great Falls Pools

Four city-run aquatic facilities offer lessons and programs year round:

Electric City Water Park can be found at River Drive and 1st Avenue South. Beat the heat with as many ways you can get wet, including body-boarding on the "Flow Rider" where 36,000 gallons of water rushes through every minute, riding the "Power Tower Plunge" and ending up in the "Lazy River," which circles a quarter-mile around the "Flow Rider" or swimming in "Mitchell Pool," Montana's largest public heated outdoor pool. Children will enjoy the wading pool and interactive play structure of the "Little Squirts Soak Zone." For those who don't want to get wet, there are large grassy areas, shade trees and a party deck. Concessions serve hot dogs, hamburgers, beverages and more fun fare. No personal coolers allowed. The water park is open through Aug. 25 and again for the weekends of Aug. 29 and Labor Day. Hours are noon-6 p.m., and on Wednesday, family nights, they're open until 8 p.m. Call the Park and Recreation Department at 771-1265 or visit the website at greatfallsmt.net/recreation for times and prices.

Neighborhood pools include the Water Tower Pool, at 34th Street and 7th Avenue South, toward the east end of the city; and the Jaycee Pool, which can be found at 4th Street and 26th Avenue Northeast in the Riverview area. Neighborhood pools are open from June 27 through Aug. 16, 1-5:45 p.m. But for the kids who just can't wait, the spray parks adjacent to each neighborhood pool can be used free of charge until June 27 and again after the pools close from Aug. 17-31. Admission to the pools is $2.50 for kids 3 to 17 and $3.50 for 18 and older. One child younger than 3 with a paying adult is free.

Morony Natatorium, 111 12th St. N., a city-operated 25-foot by 75-foot indoor pool, operates virtually year-round and is heated to 83-86 degrees. Programs include water exercise, lap swimming, kayak lessons, open swim and classes for those suffering from arthritis. Call 452-3733 for more information and to verify times.

Great Falls High School Pool, 1900 5th Ave. S., is a six-lane pool used by the school during the school year. Open swim during the summer runs Monday, Wednesday, Friday, from 1 to 3:45 p.m., Tuesday and Thursday, 1-2:45 p.m., and Monday and Wednesday, 7:30-8:45 p.m. Lap Swim in Monday-Friday, 6-7:30 a.m., and again from noon to 1 p.m. Lessons for seven different ability groups run 4-7 p.m., Monday-Friday, priced at $55-60. The pool also is available for birthday parties and other functions by calling 268-6281.

13 Great Falls Parks

Paris Gibson, the founder of Great Falls, hoped to launch a metropolis. He demanded parks, and that's what we got. His namesake is the centerpiece of the park system. Located at Park Drive and 1st Avenue North, Gibson Park features a duck pond, flower gardens, a walking path, basketball courts, restrooms and a playground. Summertime concerts take place at an outdoor band shell. A pedestrian underpass from Gibson Park takes you to Elks Riverside Park, a lesser-known but huge park along the river that features tennis courts, horseshoe pits, a skate park, playground equipment and large expanses of grass where you can fly a kite, play catch or simply relax.

Any sunny day, you'll also find people picnicking, playing games or simply lounging in the rest of the city's 400 acres developed into 57 parks. Two dozen usable public tennis courts also are scattered around the city. A complex of eight courts is available for public use at C.M. Russell High School. In addition, there are three on River Drive North near the 6th Street underpass; four at Montana Park; two each at Lions, West Kiwanis and Jaycee parks; and one each at Sunrise, Charles Russell and North Kiwanis parks. Call Parks and Recreation Administration at 771-1265 for more information.

14 Pacific Steel and Recycling Trailside Dog Park

An attractively fenced and landscaped area where dogs can "run free and play 'off leash' with their canine and human friends," the dog park, located at 800 River Drive North alongside River's Edge Trail, was opened July 15, 2009. The park was built for less than $100,000 and was financed by gifts to the Animal Foundation of Great Falls, which donated the park to the city of Great Falls. The park features a small pavilion in the middle and separate fenced and landscaped areas equipped for small and large dogs. The dividing line for dog size is 25 pounds. A paved path in the large-dog park was recently installed to protect the turf, and agility equipment on both sides of the park allows for better exercise.

Dog owners will find there is no charge to use the park, but they are still responsible for proper pet etiquette and obeying the rules of the Dog Park. Disposal bags and garbage cans are readily available, but drinking fountains for both humans and dogs are rather temperamental, so it's wise to bring your own water. The park is open from dawn to dusk, but it may be closed on occasion for maintenance or improvements. Watch the Tribune for announcements or call the Park and Recreation office at 771-1265. For more information, visit the foundation's website at www.theanimalfoundation.com.

15 First Peoples Buffalo Jump State Park

Formerly called "Ulm Pishkun," it is believed to be the largest prehistoric bison kill site in North America and has now been nominated to be designated a National Historic Landmark. The site, at 342 Ulm-Vaughn Road, consists of a mile-long sandstone cliff, remnants of drive lines and up to 18 feet of compacted buffalo remains as well as "expansive panoramic views" of the Rocky Mountain Front, the Missouri River valley and characteristic buttes and grasslands of the High Plains. Plan at least two hours at this day-use-only park for enjoying the interpretive trail, picnic tables and a protected black-tailed prairie dog town.

The site is open daily from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. until October. Admission is free for state residents or $6 per vehicle for out-of-state visitors. Call 866-2217 for more information.

16 Farmers Market

No longer just about the abundance of vegetables sold here, the Great Falls Farmers Market is held on Saturdays beginning June 6 through Sept. 26, from 7:45 a.m. to noon, in the Civic Center's Whittier Park. As the popularity of the market has grown, so has the number of vendors, so much that the market has expanded from Civic Center Park onto Park Drive and into the parking lot across the street, and a Wednesday market has been added to the schedule from July 18 to Sept. 23, 4:30-6:30 p.m. More than 100 vendors are expected to bring unique hand-crafted items of all kinds, baked goods, jams, jellies, syrups and all kinds of ready-to-eat foods. Entertainers of all ages will be scattered around the market, and there will be frequent prizes. Call 761-3881 for more information.

17 Montana State Fair

Create some new memories at the annual State Fair, running July 24-Aug. 1. Night show concert-goers will be able to enjoy performances by winners of 2015 Academy of Country Music award winners Lee Brice on July 27, Dierks Bentley July 29 and Thomas Rett on July 30. The 2015 Big Sky Rodeo Roundup, the "pinnacle in Montana rodeo" runs July 28-Aug. 1, and horse racing, now called the State Fair Race Meet, is scheduled during the fair with 10 races each day on July 18-19 and July 25-26. Post time is 1 p.m. Call 727-8900 or visit greatfallsturfclub.org.

The fair also has a full lineup of free ground acts for all ages. Come to the Central Park Stage and the South Park to find comedy acts, hypnotists, tractor pulls, exotic animals, country music and even walking on water and more. The midway showcases numerous rides, games and food, and traditional competitive exhibits include those judging livestock, youth exhibits, culinary, fine and creative arts, hobbies, floriculture and garden and farm crops. And don't forget the food, especially the famous Viking, a fried, battered meatball on a stick!

Entrance to the fair is $8 and $5 for parking; seniors and youth 6-18 are $5, and those under the age of 5 are free. The $40 Fair Fast Pass, a 9-punch card, is good for gate admission and/or parking. Visit montanastatefair.com for more information; for tickets visit goexpopark.com.

18 Great Falls Golf Courses

Great Falls has two municipal golf courses where the motto is "We'll work for you, so you can come out and play. Eagle Falls, adjacent to Legion Park at 25th Street and River Drive North, and Anaconda Hills, a short, hilly course in Black Eagle on the north side of the Missouri River, 2400 Smelter Ave. Both courses offer driving ranges as well as full pro shops and concessions. Other courses include Hickory Swing, a public course at 1100 American Ave., and Meadow Lark Country Club at the confluence of the Sun and Missouri rivers at 300 Country Club Blvd.

Eagle Falls Golf Club is an 18-hole course open to the public. Opened in 1953, it underwent a major re-design in 1999 and now plays from 5,234 to 6,571 yards as a par 71. Four sets of tees make it inviting for the casual player and extremely challenging for the avid golfer. There is also a newly designed chipping green, a putting green, practice bunker and a limited driving range. Reserve tee times two days in advance by calling 761-1078.

Anaconda Hills Golf Course is also a city-run course opened originally in the 1920s as a nine-hole course for the employees of the Anaconda Copper Co. The city acquired the course in the 1970s, and nine new holes and grass greens were added in 1992. Hilly and tree-lined with natural rough and water, the par 69 course is slightly less than 5,700 yards. Call 761-8459.

Founded in 1919, the private Meadow Lark Country Club is recognized as having one of the great classic designs with a reputation for sleek, undulating greens. The 18-hole championship course is considered one of the top 10 places to play in Montana. The club also includes a clubhouse, "award-winning pro shop, formal dining room and more casual grill room, three indoor and four outdoor tennis courts and a swimming pool open Memorial Day to Labor Day. Call 453-6531.

Hickory Swing is an 18-hole par 60 executive golf course in west Great Falls. It plays 3,731 yards over 86 acres. It was built in 1992 as a course for all skill levels. A back nine was opened in 1999, and the course has 12 par-3s and six par-4s. Hickory Swing also offers a clubhouse with pro shop and snack bar and a driving range. Open from February (weather permitting) through October, the course now opens at 6 a.m. for early-bird golfers. $20 for 18 holes, $12 for nine; call 452-9400 for available tee times.

19 The Great Falls Dams

The beautiful waterfalls east of Great Falls now are mostly covered by a series of hydroelectric dams. But glimpses of the falls so famously journaled by Lewis and Clark remain, especially when water is running high on the Missouri. Visitors have several opportunities to view these dams. Perhaps the easiest is Black Eagle Dam, which can be seen close up on the River's Edge Trail or from an overlook on River Road. Just downstream, Rainbow Dam has also been offering beautiful views since 1910 and has undergone a construction project increasing its generating capacity by 70 percent. Between these two is Cochrane Dam, part of the Great Falls Portage National Landmark, which produces 64 megawatts of electricity. Ryan Dam, the original "great falls of the Missouri," is an especially fun destination. A suspension foot bridge leads to an island from which visitors can climb to an observation point and get a full-on view of the dam. The island has a picnic and cooking area very popular with families. Morony Dam is 15 miles northeast of Great Falls. It's classified as a "run-of-river" project because it can generate electricity using the water that flows down the river without need to store additional supplies. Boaters, hikers and fishermen should call 454-5840 for current trailhead, boat launch and parking closures.

20 Black Eagle Memorial Island

Black Eagle Memorial Island opened to the public for the first time in 2005. Located just below Black Eagle Falls, the man-made island was created from material dredged out of the tailrace below the Black Eagle Dam's generation station. In the past, it was used as a parking lot for smelter workers at the former Anaconda Mining Co. complex. Today the area features a restored truss bridge, exceptional stone walls, a launch for non-motorized boats and an interpretive viewing plaza below the falls. The area is open for hiking, biking, kayaking, canoeing and fishing and is part of the new River's Edge Trail section that links West Bank Park to the island.

21 Missouri River Breaks National Monument

On a topographical map of Montana, the Missouri River Breaks look like a crumpled brown grocery bag extending west to east along the Missouri River from Fort Benton to Fort Peck. The Arrow Creek Breaks and the Musselshell Breaks contribute to the larger geographic area from the south. The Breaks, located in northcentral Montana, offer some of the finest recreational opportunities in the entire state, from river floating to hiking to hunting to horseback riding.

On the ground, the Breaks consist of rough ridges separated by steep — sometimes almost vertical — coulees. The vegetation consists of scattered Ponderosa pine, juniper, Douglas fir and mixed grasses growing in a shale/gumbo soil type. While not the most hospitable region for humans, the Breaks provide suitable habitat for an impressive list of wildlife species.

The Breaks mean different things to different people. It is defined, in part, by the history of Lewis and Clark, as a sanctuary for desperados staying a step ahead of the law and as a source of hope and inspiration for several generations of homesteaders. Some enjoy the remote area mostly for the solitude and recreational opportunities provided by the Upper Missouri River, Fort Peck Reservoir and a mixture of public and private lands. Others see the Breaks as a source of grass for livestock, natural gas, timber products and other vital pieces of our economic puzzle.

In 2001, a portion of the public land in the Breaks managed by the Bureau of Land Management, roughly 375,000 acres, was designated as the Upper Missouri River Breaks National Monument.

U.S. Highway 87 accesses the western portion of the monument at Fort Benton. On the eastern edge, U.S. Highway 101 crosses the monument and the Missouri at the James Kipp Recreation Area, and Montana Highway 236 also provides access through Lewistown, Winifred and Big Sandy.

There are no motels, service stations or restaurants in the interior of the Monument. The Missouri Breaks Interpretive Center in Fort Benton is open 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday to Friday Call 622-4000.

22 Monarch and Neihart

An hour's drive from Great Falls, these neighboring mountain towns are located in a historic mining district. The mines are closed, but the surrounding mountains are open to fun. Local creeks offer excellent fishing. There are scores of trails and backcountry roads to explore on foot, mountain bike or all-terrain vehicle. Check at trailheads for info on motorized access. Check out the easy, half-mile hike to popular Memorial Falls. Camping is available in some areas. The wildlife viewing is terrific. And winter offers a wide range of activities, including snowmobiling, downhill skiing, snowshoeing and cross-country skiing.

23 Sluice Boxes State Park

Just south of Belt, where Belt Creek slices out of the Little Belt Mountains is an area of soaring limestone cliffs and precipitous ledges, the Belt Creek Canyon and Sluice Boxes State Park. Rich in history and geologic features, the park provides excellent hiking and viewing of abundant wildlife in a wide range of habitats from shaded rock walls and miniature waterfalls to open, sun-baked slopes covered in prairie grasses. Enjoying the park, however, is not for the faint of heart. Because the train bridges were removed, hikers must ford the creek. That's nearly impossible during high water, so hiking in the Sluice Boxes is limited to the low-water season — usually mid-July through September. The creek is spring-fed and cold. Backcountry camping is allowed with permit year-round. The only facilities are the parking lot, vault toilet and the trail which follows an abandoned rail grade. Call 454-5840 or visit stateparksmt.gov/sluice-boxes.

24 Fort Benton's Riverfront

The historic community of Fort Benton, 42 miles north of Great Falls, boasts a stunning setting on the banks of the Missouri River. The site of a pre-Civil War trading post and key economic point during the "steamboat era," the town is the water gateway to the Missouri Breaks National Monument and a popular launch site for rafts and canoes. Reconstruction of three buildings of the fort is taking place; the Northeast Bastion and Blockhouse are now historically accurate. A heroic-sized statue of explorers Lewis and Clark overlooks the river along a scenic walking path. Another statue immortalizes Shep, a legendarily faithful dog. A walking bridge spans the river and offers benches for rest and reflection. There's lots to do elsewhere in town, which has two museums and a historic restored hotel, the Grand Union, which boasts a fine restaurant. From June 26 to 28, visitors may experience Montana's premier small town festival. In celebration of Chouteau County's 150th birth, the theme this year is "Footsteps Through Time." Call 750-2918.

25 Havre Beneath the Streets

The Historical Underground Tour is a recreation of Havre's history. When fire destroyed most of Havre, business owners moved underground to carry on their business until the town could be rebuilt. Step back in time as much as 100 years, into the Sporting Eagle Saloon, a turn-of-the-century honky-tonk where cowboys gambled, kicked up their heels and drank good old-fashioned frontier rot-gut. Saunter along the streets beneath Havre and see an opium den (one of three known to have existed in the early days), a Chinese laundry, an ethnic restaurant, and, of course, a bordello.

Tours are available during summer months Monday through Sunday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. with the last tour beginning at 3:30 p.m. Reservations are recommended; the ticket office is at 120 3rd Ave., south of Norman's Ranch Wear. Prices are $14 for adults, $12 for seniors 65 and older and $8 for children ages 6-12. Special evening and group tours are available upon request. Call 265-8888 for information or visit the Havre Chamber of Commerce, 518 1st St. See www.havremt.com.

The Havre Railroad Museum at 12 Third Ave., the newest museum in Havre and a must for railroad buffs, offers a brief history of the 10 different railroads that rolled through Havre in the past. Included are a relay office recreation, reference library, original hand push carts, a complete model railroad and more. It's free and open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily. Call 265-8888 or visit www.ultimatemontana.com.

26 Wahkpa Chu'gn Buffalo Jump

For an up-close look at a historic Native American site, visit the Wahkpa Chu'gn Buffalo Jump overlooking the scenic Milk River on Havre's western edge. Take a one-hour walking tour for a close-up look at the best-preserved bison kill and campsite in this area of the plains. The Brick Mural is now complete in the shadow of the Bear Paw Mountains. The site is non-sterile, so visitors may handle certain artifacts. Open June 1 to Labor Day from 9 a.m. to 4.p.m. Tours are usually available "on demand." Call 265-6417 or visit www.buffalojump.org for more information.

27 Fort Assiniboine Historic Site

Fort Assiniboine Historic Site, located 6 miles southwest of Havre on Highway 87, was constructed in 1879, and became the largest military fort west of the Mississippi River. The post had 104 buildings and was contained within a 40-mile-long by 15-mile-wide military reservation. Several of the original buildings still stand. It became a state agricultural experiment station in 1911 and is now the home of Montana State University's Northern Agricultural Research Center. The primary mission of the fort's garrison was to prevent attacks from the some 5,000 Lakota Sioux Indians led by Sitting Bull, and other chiefs who had fled to the safety of Canada after the Battle of the Little Big Horn.

The fort served as a base for patrols along the Canadian border and the Milk River Valley. Fort Assiniboine became the state's military headquarters, with the responsibility of maintaining control over the Blackfoot Confederacy and other northern Montana Indian reservations. The most famous soldier to serve at the fort was John J. Pershing, who was assigned to the post in 1896. He commanded H Troop, the black "Buffalo Soldiers" of the 10th Cavalry. The Fort Assiniboine Preservation Society offers summer tours from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., Mon.-Fri., and by appointment for the weekends. For additional information, call 262-7656.

The Northern Agricultural Research Center will celebrate its 100th anniversary with several events including the annual field day and tours July 1 with the first tour beginning at 1 p.m. The new office building will be dedicated, and agri-business awards presented. Call 265-6115.

28 Charlie Russell Chew Choo

Experience the beauty of rolling hills, vast ranch lands and breathtaking sunsets from the comfort of a vintage train; possibly masked bandits may even stage a hold-up when least expected. Now beginning at Kingston Junction, near Lewistown, and crossing three trestle bridges on its route to Denton and back, the 3.5 hour trip offers includes a full course prime rib dinner, dessert, no-host cash bar and musical entertainment. Built on the spur track connecting Lewistown and Great Falls 100 years ago, the five 1950-vintage stainless steel cars make 12 trips between May 10 and Oct. 3. Reservations are encouraged and can be made at montana-dinertrain.com or by calling 535-5436.

29 Freezout Lake

Freezout Lake and its surrounding 11,466 acres, is a prime hot spot for bird lovers in Montana. In spring, hundreds of thousands of migrating snow geese stop at Freezout for a rest before flying north to Canada's Alberta and Saskatchewan, and then to nesting grounds at the Arctic coast. Park officials recommend viewing from sunrise to 10 a.m. and from 4:30 p.m. to dusk in early March, but wildlife viewing is available year round. For a more enjoyable experience, stay for a maximum of 14 days. Bring binoculars or telescope, a light lunch and warm clothing. Call 467-2646 or 467-2488.

30 Chokecherry Festival

The 26th annual festival is scheduled for Sept. 12 in Lewistown. The chokecherry, a small, maroon-colored, tart fruit that grows wild in Montana, will reign supreme on the first Saturday after Labor Day. The festival traditionally is attended by close to 4,000 people. The day starts with the Kiwanis Club serving an outdoor breakfast at Main Street and Second Avenue. On the menu are pancakes with chokecherry syrup. From pit-spitting and culinary contests to streets lined with arts and crafts booths and food vendors and from a 5k and 1-mile run/walk to children's activities, there's something for everyone. 31 Other Lewistown Area Events and Destinations

Visitors will want to include the tours departing Wednesday through Sunday at 10 a.m. for the Bear Gulch Pictographs located 23 miles southeast of Lewistown in the foothills of the Little Snowy Mountains (visit beargulch.net for information), the 30th Montana Cowboy Poetry Gathering at the Yogo Inn and Conference Center, celebrating the history and heritage of the American Cowboy of the upper Rocky Mountain west, Aug. 13-16 (538-4575), the Aug. 8 Montana Island Challenge, runs and/or hikes sponsored by four nonprofit organizations to benefit children in Central Montana (535-2257) and Missouri Breaks Historical Homesteader Auto Tour, a 4-5 hour tour of the remote areas of Fergus County settled during the Homestead Act era between 1903 and 1918. 32 Blaine County Wildlife Museum

Located at 417 Indiana St., in the Chinook downtown business district, the project began in 1991 when the Blaine Theater building was donated by the Blaine Bank of Montana. It features more than 200 animal displays set in natural habitats and a gift shop with works from Montana artists, carvers and taxidermists. Museum hours are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Saturday, and 1-5 p.m. Sunday, from June 1 through Aug. 31. Admission is $6 for adults and $4 for students. Call 357-2385 or visit www.bcwildlifemuseum for more information.

33 Bear Paw Battlefield

Fifteen miles south of Chinook on Route 240 is the battlefield that commemorates the end of the Nez Perce War of 1877. The flight of the Nez Perce, led by Chief Joseph from Army soldiers, took them from Oregon, through Idaho, into Montana and almost to the Canadian border before they were defeated. Here the tribe split up, with some heading to Canada and others to Nebraska. The Nez Perce ceased fighting at Bear Paw on Oct. 5, 1877, and Chief Joseph gave his immortal speech, "From where the sun now stands, I will fight no more forever." The battlefield is open daily year-round during daylight hours but closed for lunch from noon to 1 p.m. Visitors may walk a self-guided 1.25-mile interpretive trail of moderate difficulty and are encouraged to visit the Blaine County Museum at 501 Indiana St. in Chinook and see the audio/visual presentation "40 Miles to Freedom" before touring the battlefield. There are no fees. Call 406-357-2590.

34 Benton Lake National Wildlife Refuge

Located at 922 Bootlegger Trail and administered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Benton Lake National Wildlife Refuge is a 13-square-mile oasis of grasslands and wetlands lying within a sea of agriculture. Mountain ranges surround three sides, forming a backdrop to a scene that reminds visitors of the days when the entire prairie-wetland ecosystem was alive with thousands of different birds. Benton Lake was created thousands of years ago by the continental glacier, and the area was excluded from homesteading in 1885 in order to provide an irrigation district. Animals abound in the refuge and include water birds such as ducks, Canada geese, snow geese and tundra swans. Also common are sightings of dozens of species of mammals, including mountain cottontail, American badger, striped skunk and long-tailed weasel. Ten numbered signs along the Wildlife Auto Tour correspond to a map provided at the information kiosk at the beginning of the drive, helping visitors reflect on species, habitat, history and management of Benton Lake NWR. Follow Highway 87 north out of Great Falls about 1 mile and turn left onto Bootlegger Trail. Then go about 9 miles to the refuge entrance. The visitor center is open 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., Monday to Friday Call 406-727-7400.

35 The Annual Montana Atlatl Mammoth Hunt

Experts and novices from around the country, and even the world, come to try their hand at throwing the atlatl, an 8,000-year-old hunting weapon, and occasionally the primitive bow, tomahawk and knife. Regional members of the World Atlatl Association in conjunction with First Peoples Buffalo State Park set targets along one section of the trail. Participants are required to walk the trail, so bring hiking boots or comfortable shoes. Hunts are set for Sept. 5-6. Call 866-2217 for further information.

36 Fort Peck Lake Reservoir and Recreation Area

Behind the 3.8 mile long Fort Peck Dam — the world's largest hydroelectric earthen dam — is the state's largest body of water, Fort Peck Lake Reservoir. It is surrounded by 1,520 miles of shoreline — that's more than California has with the Pacific Ocean. The fishing is great with more than 50 kinds of fish, including walleye, bass, ling and salmon, northern pike, perch and sauger. Open Memorial Day to Labor Day, the shore also offers camping, boating and swimming. A paved road for larger vehicles provides access to the reservoir at Fort Peck Marina; all other access roads are gravel or dirt. The C.M. Russell Wildlife Refuge surrounds the body of water and consists of more than 1 million acres available for hiking, camping, fishing and other recreation. Call 526-3411.

For a total change of pace, check out the Fort Peck Summer Theatre, now celebrating its 46th season with five great family-friendly shows: "Always…Patsy Cline" May 29-June 7; "One Man. Two Guvnors" June 12-28; "Best Little Whorehouse in Texas" July 10-26; "Tarzan" July 31-Arg. 16; and "Steel magnolias" Aug. 21-Sept. 6. Performances are Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m., with Sunday matinees at 4 p.m. Tickets are $17 for adults, $12 for students and $5 for preschool. Call 526-9943 for reservations.

37 Fort Peck Interpretive Center

Opened in 2005 near the massive Fort Peck Dam, the $6.7 million interpretive center is the result of a partnership between Fort Peck Paleontology Inc., the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Army Corps of Engineers. The 18,000-square-foot building's most impressive feature is in the cathedral-like lobby — it's a 40-foot-long replica of Tyrannosaurus Rex, affectionately known as "Peck's Rex." The museum also features 10 fleshed-out head mounts of other prehistoric beasts, as well as a wildlife display with full-body mounts of elk, badgers, deer and other native species. Two of Montana's largest aquariums showcase the many species of fish in the Fort Peck Reservoir and the Missouri River. Summer interpretive programs include hands-on children's programs and nature walks on the 3-mile nature trail. Adjacent to the Center is a Class A campground and day use recreation area with picnic shelters, playground equipment, basketball and volleyball courts and horseshoe pits. Power House tours are conducted Monday-Fridy four times a day (9 and 11 a.m., 1 and 3 p.m.); Saturday and Sunday tours are hourly beginning at 9 a.m. with the last tour at 4 p.m. Call 526-3493.

38 Valley County Pioneer Museum

The Pioneer Museum is home to a chronological history of the region from the age of dinosaurs to the present day. It includes one of the largest Assiniboine material culture collections in the world. It features memorabilia from the pioneer days, as well as the county's Basque sheep-herding era. It also houses extensive genealogical archives and a Western Reading Room. Call in advance to schedule tours at 406-228-8692. Open daily from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Adults $3, ages 7-21 $2, free for ages 6 and under.





39 Great Plains Dinosaur Museum

In 2003, members of Malta's community formed to care for the "unique dinosaur discoveries of Phillips County." A tire shop was converted in the Dinosaur Field Station where fossils of the area were cleaned and studied. In 2006, they received state funding for the creation of the museum. Opened in 2008, the 3,000-square-foot Great Plains Dinosaur Museum showcases a "stunning variety" of real fossils of fish, squids, lobsters and rare crabs, plants and some of Montana's best-preserved dinosaurs, including Triceratops, Stegasaurus, Sauropod, raptor Dromesaurus and Handrosaurus. For young dinosaur fanatics, the Museum offers Junior Paleontologist programs during the summer. Located on Highway 2 East at 405 1st St. NE in Malta, the museum is open 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday.-Saturday, and 12:30-5 p.m. on Sundays. Call 654-1578.

Also on U.S. 2, the Phillips County Museum honors its mission to preserve and interpret the rich heritage of the Hi-Line area, including dinosaurs, Indians, cowboys, pioneers and outlaws. Highlights include a life-size replica of a cowboy bunkhouse, one-room schoolhouse, church and mercantile and an exhibit on native-son outlaw, Kid Curry, which includes artifacts from his time with the Wild Bunch. Information is available through the museums and field station. Find the museum at the junction of U.S. Highways 2 and 191 in Malta. Hours are Monday-Saturday 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Call 654-1037.

40 Outlaw Trail

Outlaws of all stripes — including Kid Curry, Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid, Dutch Henry and the Hole-in-the-Wall gang — all holed up in the part of Montana at various times. Visitors interested in their turn-of-the-century exploits can still check out several sites along the so-called Outlaw Trail. Start in Scobey, near the beginning of the trail, where Dutch Henry and his gang frequently hung out at the Dug Out Saloon. Much of the history is captured at the Daniels County Museum and Pioneer Town, where 35 historic buildings were restored to depict a town in the early part of the century. If you're in Scobey the last weekend in June, stop by for Pioneer Days, featuring the (family-friendly) Dirty Shame Show. Call 406-487-5965 to confirm dates. Historic walking tours with interpretive signs are available in the area.

41 C.M. Russell Wildlife Refuge

Covering more than a million acres in northeast Montana and extending 125 airline miles up the Missouri River from Fort Peck Dam, the Charles M. Russell National Wildlife Refuge includes a vast range of wildlife and topography. Native prairie, forested coulees, river bottoms, badlands often portrayed in the paintings by Charlie Russell, and the huge Fort Peck Reservoir all are encompassed in the refuge. Excellent wildlife viewing and photographic opportunities of mule and white-tailed deer, antelope, bighorn sheep, elk, coyotes, waterfowl, upland game birds, badgers, bobcats, mountain lions and prairie dogs. In the fall, visitors may listen to elk bugle and defend harems at the Slippery Ann Elk viewing Area. UL Bend NWR, which lies within the Russell Refuge, is a reintroduction site for the endangered black-footed ferret. Camping is permitted anywhere on the range, and it is open to hiking and horseback riding although no formal trails exist. Seasonal road closures begin in late August. Refuge headquarters are located in Lewistown. To limit erosion and to protect plants and wildlife, mechanized vehicles are permitted only on numbered refuge roads designated as open. Call Complex headquarters at 538-7521.
