42 Blackfeet Indian Reservation

While most of the members of Montana's largest Indian tribe, the Blackfeet, live much like mainstream Western society, they also have maintained traditions such as the use of painted tepees, colorful headdresses and deerskin costumes on special occasions. The Museum of the Plains Indian, near the intersection of U.S. Highways 2 and 89 in Browning, has a comprehensive collection of cultural artifacts and exhibits as well as a gift shop featuring a wide variety of Native American art and jewelry. Interpreter-guided tours, offering a deeper look at the history of the Blackfeet people, begin at the Museum of the Plains Indian and cover sites such as Sun Dance, Buffalo Jumps, Tepee Rings, Holy Family Mission and Fort McLeod Road. The museum is open Tuesday-Saturday, 9 a.m.-4:45 p.m., through Labor Day. Call 338-2230. Although Browning is its center, resort towns St. Mary and East Glacier are located on the eastern edge of Glacier National Park within the boundaries of the reservation.

During the 64th annual North American Indian Days, July 9-12, tepees will be pitched on the powwow ground for "four days of contest dancing, games, sports, events and socializing." Call 338-7406 for more information. The Heart Butte Society Celebration will be held Aug. 6-9 at Heart Butte, a town 26 miles south of Browning.

43 Glacier National Park

The breathtaking vistas of Glacier National Park draw visitors from all over the world. This 1-million-acre national park preserves some of America's most gorgeous country — including 106 miles of the Continental Divide — and the abundant wildlife that inhabits its wilderness.

Glacier National Park has been revered by the Plains Indians for many generations. Archeologists have found evidence of human activity in the Glacier Park area that dates back 10,000 years. These early people may have been the ancestors of the Blackfeet, Salish and Kootenai Indians. Meriwether Lewis came close to the southern tip of Glacier in 1806, checking how far north the Missouri River watershed extended. White explorers kept searching for the perfect mountain pass through which to run a railroad line over the Rockies. Although many of the region's Native Americans knew the location of Marias Pass, the Blackfeet guarded it closely. In 1889, an explorer for the Great Northern Railway, John F. Stevens, finally figured out where Marias Pass lay. Marias was the lowest mountain pass between Canada and Mexico. Its low altitude and easy grade made it perfect for trains to cross the Continental Divide. The mountains east of the Continental Divide were acquired from the Blackfeet in 1895 and designated a national wilderness forest preserve in 1900, opening it to mining. President William Howard Taft signed the bill to establish Glacier as a national park in 1910.

Portions of the Going-to-the-Sun Road remain open all year, but unpredictable spring snow storms can slow plowing progress. For current road status, visit home.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/hours.htm. Other roads open in May, weather permitting. The summer rate for a 7-day vehicle (non-commercial car, truck or van) permit is $25 with the 7-day single-entry price for visitors traveling by foot, bicycle, motorcycle or in a non-commercial organized group is set at $12. There is no entrance fee on Aug. 25 and Sept. 26.

There are 700 miles of hiking trails, and many visitors wouldn't miss a chance to hike along the Garden Wall. Campers have a choice of about 1,200 first-come, first-serve campsites accessible by vehicle, and permits are available for 13 country front campgrounds. The historic Many Glacier Hotel has recently undergone a $10 million renovation, but historic hotels book up fast; call Glacier Park Inc. at 892-2525 or Apgar Village Lodge at 888-5484.Tour buses and boats are available seasonally, and guided hiking trips and American Indian interpretive tours are also available. Many visitors also make arrangements to cross the border into Waterton Lakes National Park on the Canadian side of the Waterton-Glacier International Peace Park.

44 Izaak Walton Inn

Located just off Highway 2 at Essex, on the southern tip of Glacier National Park, is the picturesque Izaak Walton Inn. It was built in 1939 for train crews on the Great Northern Railway. Today it's a popular inn, restaurant and mini railroad museum. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The dining room walls are covered with old photographs and prints of trains. "Relaxation is key," and "room telephones are absent" in the inn. For a different experience, rent one of the four old cabooses that have been converted into overnight lodging or stay in one of six new family cabins. Additional lodging is now available in the GN 441 Luxury Locomotive which features 44-year-old reclaimed oak floors and a full kitchen, and the JJ Caboose, named for James Jerome Hill, the Empire Builder of the Great Northern Railway, for an unsurpassed cozy western retreat. The trains still run past the inn, with passenger service available. And Essex is a great place from which to find a trailhead into the surrounding mountains. You may also book Glacier interpretive Red Bus tours or whitewater raft trips from the inn. For information or reservations, call 406-888-5700 or visit www.izaakwaltoninn.com.

45 Flathead Valley

In the northwest corner of Montana lies the picturesque Flathead Valley. A hub for tourism, the valley sits next to Glacier National Park and is overflowing with activity. From hiking, fishing, boating and golfing in the summer to cross-country or downhill skiing in the winter, the only thing visitors will wish for more of is time. Flathead Lake is the largest natural freshwater lake west of the Mississippi River, and the resort town, Bigfork, situated at its north shore, is a picturesque town with a 27-hole golf course, Eagle Bend Golf Club (837-7310). Family fun abounds in the area, with the Big Sky Water Park in Columbia Falls (892-5025) and numerous fresh huckleberry and Flathead cherry stands scattered throughout the valley. Hungry Horse Dam is the 11th largest concrete dam in the United States, and its spillway is the highest morning-glory structure in the world. During the summer, the visitor center is open from 7:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. Call 387-5241. Boating, fishing, hiking and camping are available at the reservoir. Kalispell, the largest city in the valley, is home of the Conrad Mansion, built in 1895 by the city's founder, as well as a picturesque downtown shopping area with tons of local flavor. Call the Flathead Convention and Visitors Bureau at 800-543-3105.

46 Saint Ignatius Mission

Built in 1854 by Native Americans under the supervision of Catholic missionaries who came to convert the locals, the Mission's setting is beautiful, with the Mission Mountains in the background. The striking building features 61 original murals along its walls and on its ceiling. These are by Joseph Carignano, a Jesuit priest who served at the mission. The mission is open for private worship 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. in the summer with Sunday Mass at 9:15 a.m. Reservations are not accepted, but walk-ins are welcome. Gift shop on site. Call 745-2768.

47 Moiese National Bison Range

Established in 1908, the 19,000-acre National Bison range is located on the Flathead Indian Reservation in the Mission Valley. Self-guided, drive-through tours are available to observe the more than 400 bison, deer, elk, antelope and birds that make their home on the preserve. Red Sleep Mountain Drive is open during the summer while the winter drive is no longer open to two-way traffic. No motorcycles or bicycles are allowed for the safety of the animals and visitors. Visit the range in spring for the abundant wild flowers and in October to watch the annual bison round up, a hugely popular event. New restrictions exclude longer vehicles as well as any trailer or towed vehicle. Visitors' Center is open daily 10 a.m.-2 p.m., but the front gate is open 6:00 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.

48 Whitefish Mountain Resort

Opening day is June 20! Located on the edge of Whitefish and just west of Glacier Park, Whitefish Mountain Resort is a world-class downhill ski destination. It offers lodging, restaurants, lots of activities and some of the best views in the area. That goes for summer, too. Take the 15-minute gondola ride to the top of the mountain and witness stunning vistas of Glacier Park and the surrounding area. Have lunch, and then hop the gondola for the trip down. Better yet, take the scenic walking trail. The Zipline Tour is for adventurous visitors who will strap on a paragliding-style harness and click onto a custom built cable trolley to fly 300 feet off the ground at speeds up to 50 mph! People of all ability levels may enjoy the Aerial Adventure Park where they can learn to navigate treetop courses. In July and August wildflower walks are offered. Other guided tours are also available. Visit skiwhitefish.com.

49 Flathead Lake

Flathead Lake is the most popular — and most used — water playground in the state. It's the largest natural freshwater lake in the Western states. The lake is 28 miles long and, at its widest, 15 miles across. Maximum depth is 386 feet. Anglers delight in the fishing. The lake is known for its lake trout, cutthroat trout, perch, bass and whitefish. State parks along the lake offer great access for boating, swimming and camping. The lake is popular for speed boating, sailing, jet skiing, canoeing, kayaking and parasailing. Small islands offer great opportunities to observe birds and wildlife. There's lots of lodging and restaurants available along different stretches of the shore.

50 Yaak Falls

This waterfall is the highlight for many visitors as they tour through the Yaak area in extreme northwest Montana. During spring and early summer tremendous viewing opportunities abound in the Yaak River area as snowmelt follows its way down and over the falls. For any photographer, this is one sight that shouldn't be missed. This site can be found on a Kootenai National Forest Visitors Map at Township 33N, Range 33W, Section 9. The Yaak Falls, named after the Yaak Indians who once populated this remote area of Montana, has always been a favorite stop on the scenic tour of northwest Montana. This beautifully cascading waterfall was created by the eastward shift of the Pacific plate. As a result of this shifting, some of the oldest rock in the world is exposed. The rock is dated between 800 million and 11/2 billion years old. This area is rich in local history, dating back to the 1880s. Part of an old bridge can be seen just below the falls. This bridge was the first structure to span the Yaak River. This allowed unrestricted passage from Troy to another important mining town called Sylvanite. Many placer mining camps, including one called "Snipe Town," operated near the falls in the 1890s. In 1910, a devastating fire destroyed mining operations around the falls area. The Yaak Falls Campground is a little pack-in, pack-out campground with a maximum stay of 14 days and no fees. No toilets or drinking water are available. Call 295-4693.

51 Hot Springs

Hot Springs, founded in 1910, is named for the local hot mineral springs that still bubble today. Thousands of people seeking rest and relief from pressure travel to the town of Hot Springs to bathe in the fine mineral water and mud baths. Many revisit on a regular basis, enjoying the benefits and relief that the natural hot mineral waters bring in the treatment of arthritis, skin diseases, rheumatism, stomach ulcers, high blood pressure and many other ailments. Opportunities for privacy, quietness, and relaxation abound in this area. Many lakes, streams and rivers provide excellent fishing for the avid fisherman. Nearby sight-seeing attractions include a tour of the National Bison Range at Moiese, a visit to the historical St. Ignatius Mission Church and Flathead Lake with its many opportunities for boating, jet skiing, water skiing and fishing.

52 Seeley Lake

Named for the lake it abuts, Seeley Lake is a small town quickly growing in popularity with tourists. In winter, it's known for great snowmobiling, cross-country skiing, dog sledding and ice fishing. Summer recreation is even more plentiful. The lake itself offers camping, boating, swimming and fishing. Nearby trails head off into both the Bob Marshall and Mission Mountain wilderness areas. Folks on mountain bikes and all-terrain vehicles love all the old logging roads. The Clearwater River, which runs south through the valley, and the Swan River which flows north, offer fishing and canoeing. Golfers enjoy the nine-hole mountain course and more at Double Arrow Resort on the south edge of town. Call the Seeley Lake Area Chamber of Commerce at 677-2880.

Several guest ranches offer horseback riding. There's camping and boating also available at nearby Swan Lake and Placid Lake. Just a short drive from Seeley Lake is the trailhead to Morrell Falls. A fairly flat, 2.5-mile hike leads to a stunning drop of falls — and a great place for a picnic. The hike is popular with families because children often enjoy splashing in Morrell Creek below the falls. Bring drinking water.

53 The Sweet Palace

Indulge your sweet tooth at the Sweet Palace at 109 E. Broadway in Philipsburg, and view what nostalgic, sumptuous sweets are cooking. Choose from 50 kinds of fudge, more than 72 flavors of saltwater taffy, 20 varieties of caramels or luxurious hand-dipped chocolates. You can even watch as they make their own caramels, toffees, brittles and marshmallow or create your personal favorites at the Copper Cauldron. Go online to sweetpalace.com or call 859-3353. During the summer, they're open 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. but are closed on Saturdays.

54 A Carousel for Missoula

Located in Missoula's Caras Park, the colorful carousel is a gift to the city from one man's dream — and the volunteer work of many others. In 1991, cabinet builder Chuck Kaparich told city residents that if they'd provide a home for it, he'd build the carousel. When it opened four years later, more than 100,000 volunteer hours were logged on the project. Locals volunteered time and materials. The result: 38 hand-carved ponies, two chariots, 14 gargoyles and the largest band organ in continuous use in the country. A carving organization in Calgary, Alberta, even carved a friendship horse for the project. It's all contained within a building that looks like a jewel box. Dragons Hollow, the play area for children was added next to the carousel in 1995. Hours are 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. June-August. Call 549-8382.

55 Historical Museum at Fort Missoula

Community members joined together in 1974 to save what was left of the historic 1877 Fort Missoula which had housed the black 25th Infantry in 1888 and served as a military training center during World War I, regional headquarters of the Civilian Conservation Corps in 1933 and as an alien detention center in 1941. The post was decommissioned in 1947. Today the museum is the collection point for history and memorabilia of the Missoula area. Located on 32 acres, it houses 13 structures and more than 25,000 artifacts. Current exhibits include "Growing the Garden City: Missoula's First 50 Years" and "The Road to Today: 250 Years of Missoula's History." Open 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Monday to Saturday and Noon -5 p.m. on Sunday. Call 728-3476 or visit www.fortmissoulamuseum.org.

56 Hike-the-M in Missoula

Visitors to Missoula can gain a dizzying view of the campus of University of Montana with a short but steep hike to Mount Sentinel's M in Missoula. The M-hike is an ideal family activity, but the more ambitious hiker may consider tackling Sentinel itself. Reaching the summit is a bit more strenuous than the M, with an elevation gain of almost 2,000 feet in about one mile. From the summit, hikers have several options to extend their hike or descend the same way they came up. Mt. Jumbo, Mt. Sentinel's sister peak, branded with an L for Loyola High School, offers a climb of barely a mile, but there are fewer switchbacks to help with the climb.

57 Alberton Gorge

Some 30 miles west of Missoula on the Clark Fork River is the Alberton Gorge, the area's premier whitewater run for rafting and kayaking. It features Class III water, as well as quiet pools for swimming and fishing. Floaters are treated to many varieties of birds and wildlife, dramatic cliffs and roller-coaster rapids. Local companies offer full-day and half-day float trips. Only experienced floaters should hit the rapids without a guide. Call 722-7238 for more information.

58 Travelers' Rest State Park

Located south of Lolo in the Bitterroot Valley, Travelers' Rest marks the old Indian campsite used by Lewis and Clark in both 1805 and 1806 as they made their way through the area. In recent years archaeologists found evidence of the expedition's main cook fire and latrine, which confirmed the explorers had been there. Activities for visitors include bird watching, children's activities, educational programs and fly fishing. Open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. throughout the summer, the visitors' center opens at 9 a.m. The entrance is located ½ mile west of Lolo. Call 273-4253 or visit www.travelersrest.org.

59 Garnet Ghost Town

"To walk the streets of this ghost town is to step back in time, free from intrusion of modern society!"A former gold-mining camp east of Missoula, Garnet once boasted some 1,000 residents, a school, many businesses and 13 bars. But by 1912 the gold had played out and a raging fire sent most of the remaining residents packing. Today, Garnet is now considered the state's best-preserved ghost town. Garnet is open to tourists. Open year-round, but access is limited to snowmobile or cross-country skis in winter. For access instructions and restrictions, visit garnetghosttown.net or call 329-3914.

GOLD WEST COUNTRY

60 Virginia City

Virginia City — and the nearby Nevada City — had their glory days during the 1860s gold rush. Seemingly frozen in time, much of their splendor is well preserved, and Virginia City now is a hot destination for history buffs and others seeking a window on the state's past. Virginia City is a National Historic Landmark, a very much alive ghost town that boasts a tremendous collection of old-west memorabilia. Many of the buildings are restored and now give visitors a real-life feel of the past. The Nevada City Living History Museum is open every summer. The summer of 2014 will be filled with fun events celebrating the sesquicentennial of finding gold in Alder Gulch and the cultural heritage of Virginia City. Events are planned every weekend through Labor Day, and there are opportunities for fun and learning throughout the season. A complete calendar of events, is available under the events tab on the Virginia City Area Chamber of Commerce Web site at www.virginiacity.com or by calling 1-800-829-2969.

61 Grant-Kohrs Ranch

Once the headquarters of a 10 million acre cattle empire and now a 1,600 acre working cattle ranch, the Grant-Kohrs Ranch near Deer Lodge is run by the National Park Service. It showcases the development of the cattle industry over the last 150 years with 80 historical structures including a ranch house, bunkhouse and outbuildings which operate much today as they did in the late 1800s and commemorate the role of cattlemen in American history. Visitors may reflect on Montana's early ranch days by beginning guided tours at the main ranch house. The visitors' center is open daily from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and until 5:30 from Memorial Day through Labor Day. Call 846-2070.

62 Bannack State Park

The first major gold strike in Montana was in Bannack. The mining camp quickly swelled to a bustling town of 3,000. It was the first territorial capital of Montana and became home to the infamous Sheriff Henry Plummer and the Vigilantes. Located about 25 miles south of Dillon on Grasshopper Creek, Bannack became a state park in 1954. Visitors can walk the boardwalk and enjoy the many buildings that have been preserved as part of this National Historic Landmark. History comes alive the third weekend of July each year during Bannack Days. Get in on the first annual Living History Days in September where re-enactors will depict the first 20 years of Bannack history. There are self-guided tours year round and guided tours by special request. Visitors may have fun panning for gold on their own and will enjoy "Saturdays in the Park" with a special project presented each Saturday in the summer. Camping is available year round, and check out the tepee during the summer season. The townsite is open 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. from Memorial Day through Labor Day. Call 834-3413.

63 Lewis and Clark Caverns State Park

Located on Montana Highway 2, 19 miles west of Three Forks or 17 miles east of Whitehall, the Lewis and Clark Caverns became Montana's first state park in 1937. Located on 3,000 acres along the Jefferson River, the caverns are filled with geological wonders — stalactites, stalagmites and stunning columns. Visitors can take a two-hour, two-mile guided tour through the large caverns and narrow passages. The limestone caverns remain a cool 50 degrees during even the hottest of days. The park also includes a 40-space campground, amphitheater, visitor center, 3 rental cabins, picnic area, hiking trails, RV hookups, showers, firewood, and toilets. Bring good hiking shoes and bottled water. The trek to the entrance can be tough on little ones, and strollers or backpacks are not allowed on the tour. Summer cave tours run from May 1 to Sept. 30, but campgrounds and cabins are open all year. Tours are scheduled from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. and are open until 7 p.m. midsummer. Call 406-287-3541.

64 Old Montana Prison

Built by convict labor in the late 1800s, this old-style prison was in use until 1979 and was home to at least one member of the "Wild Bunch." It is now on the National Register of Historic Places. Guided and self-guided tours take visitors through the massive cell block that once housed the state's worst prisoners. Sandstone walls are 24 feet high and buried 4 feet deep to prevent escape by tunneling. A museum now adjoins the prison. It is open year round seven days a week from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m., with last admission time at 5:10 p.m. Call 406-846-3111.

The old prison also houses an auto museum with more than 150 cars, from classic Chevys to a 1903 Ford, on display. It was recently listed as one of the top 10 car museums in the country by USA Today.

65 Old Works Golf Course

Anaconda's history is built on copper smelting, but that history left a dirty legacy — a Superfund clean-up site. In the 1980s, the idea arose to transform the Old Works smelting site into something more useful. Today, the Old Works Golf Course is the state's only Jack Nicklaus signature golf course, and is quickly building a reputation as one of the premier daily-fee golf experiences in the Northwest region. It features multiple tees, allowing players of all levels to enjoy the challenging 18 holes. The course design includes some of the byproducts of the mining days. Huge piles of black slag are incorporated into the design. It's also used in the bunkers. Measuring up to 7,700 yards, the course runs along Warm Springs Creek. Fairways are bordered by native grasses planted as part of the restoration process. Nicklaus also designed the practice facility — putting area, chipping/bunker area, two bent-grass practice tees and three practice holes. Also available are a clubhouse, dining room and bar and pro shop. Call 563-5989 for prices and tee times.

66 Big Hole National Battlefield

The site of a battle between the Nez Perce Indians and the 7th U.S. Infantry forces and civilian volunteers in 1877 as five bands of Nez Perce were fleeing the government's attempt to confine them on a small reservation in Idaho. The battlefield offers three separate trails allowing visitors access to the actual locations where the events took place. Trail guides are available at the trailheads, and a Summer Speaker Series begins on June 29 and continues every weekend through Aug. 18. The main visitor center is open 9 a.m.-5 p.m. daily. From Wisdom, take State Highway 43 west for 10 miles or east for 16 miles from Lost Trail Pass junction with U.S. Highway 93 on the Montana-Idaho border. Call 689-3155.

67 Berkeley Pit

By the end of the 19th century, Butte claimed fame as the Richest Hill on Earth. In 1955, copper mining in the area greatly expanded with the opening of the Berkeley Pit. By 1980, with more than 1.5 billion tons of material removed from the town's main mine, all that was left was the pit. The large, truck-operated, open-pit copper mine was world famous while in operation. Two small communities and much of Butte's former east side were swallowed up by the mine following land purchases for expansion. Now a superfund site, the pit is 7,000 feet long, 5,600 feet wide and 1,600 feet deep. It is slowly filling with water. Visitors can look at the colors of the pit from the viewing stand. Call 497-6250.

68 Our Lady of the Rockies

Towering 90 feet tall on the mountains overlooking Butte is Our Lady of the Rockies, a statue dedicated to all women, regardless of religion. Built entirely by volunteers, the statue was begun in 1979 and completed in 1985. That year, in a breath-taking operation, an Air National Guard team raised the 51-ton statue by Sky Crane helicopter onto its mountainside base. Today visitors can go inside the towering metal structure. During summer and early fall, tour buses take visitors to the site. A 2½ hours. Open June through October, Mon. - Sat. Hours are 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., opening 1 hour later on Sun. Tours lasting 2½ hours run from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Mon.-Sat. and Sun. at 11 a.m., weather permitting. Please call ahead. Prices range from $2 to $15 depending on age. Call 782-1221.

69 Fairmont Hot Springs Resort

Heated with natural hot springs, Fairmont Hot Springs' pools are a year-round attraction for locals and tourists. The resort includes two Olympic-sized swimming pools and two mineral soaking pools — one of each located both indoors and out. A featured attraction is its five-story, 350-foot enclosed waterslide, which provides thrills for all ages. The resort has its own hotel, café, dining room, lounge, snack bar and conference center. Whispering Willows Spa services are available. Also on site is a 6,741-yard, 18-hole golf course. Its "mile-high, mile-long" fifth hole is considered one of the most challenging in the state. It's "the Best of Montana All in One Place." Call 797-3241.

70 Georgetown Lake

Located about 20 west miles of Anaconda, for boaters, campers, fishers and windsurfers, Georgetown Lake is a popular outdoor recreation site. The 6,000-foot mountain lake is in a stunning setting, surrounded by the Flint Creek Range to the north and the Pintlers to the south. Anglers prize the lake for its Kokanee salmon and rainbow trout. The lake features four public boat ramps. Camping is available, as are lodging, restaurants, casinos and a marina.

71 Boulder Hot Springs

Founded a century ago, Boulder Hot Springs is a historic hotel situated on the grounds of natural geothermal water. For most of the past 100 years, visitors have ventured here to soak and swim in the warm, relaxing water of the mineral-laden waters, the outdoor swimming pool or natural mineral steam rooms. The hotel was recently restored and includes a bed and breakfast. It's the perfect place for a conference or retreat. Famous for its buffets, spa services are also enjoyed by many visitors. The resort is backed by the Deerlodge National Forest — home to bears, moose, elk, deer, fox, antelope and coyotes. Open 10 a.m. to 9 p.m. April 1-October 31 and noon to 8 p.m. November 1-March 31. Call 406-225-4339.

72 Gates of the Mountains

The Gates of the Mountains Recreation Area at upper Holter Lake is located about 20 miles north of Helena and is a famous part of the route of the Lewis and Clark expedition. A guided boat tour from the marina provides visitors with an in-depth look at the area's geography, wildlife and history. The canyon is home to scores of creatures, including mountain sheep, deer, otters, turkey vultures and even the occasional black bear. Although the 2007 Meriwether fire scorched a large part of the area, vegetation is abundant. The canyon like waterway is actually home to some plants that can't be found anywhere else. Tour guides aboard the boats say the area is a "geologist's playground." Passengers have the option to stop off at the Meriwether Picnic Area, stay awhile and catch a later boat back. There are restroom facilities, a large, covered picnic structure for group gatherings and smaller individual sites with grills and tables. Hikers can tackle the jaunt to the Mann Gulch, where a forest fire killed 13 smokejumpers in 1949, or the Gates of the Mountains Wilderness. The Gates was also a significant site for Native American culture. Tour guides said the area had a deep spiritual implication which still can be seen in the pictographs painted onto the cliffs' nooks and crannies. Call 458-5241 or email tours@gatesofthemountains.com for tour schedules and prices and to make reservations.

73 Montana State Capitol

Since its restoration, the Montana State Capitol is a destination in its own right. The main area of the Capitol was built in 1902; two wings were added a decade later. The building is built of sandstone and granite. Atop its copper dome is a statue depicting liberty. A gift shop and museum are located just down the street in the Montana Historical Society, which offers 1-hour guided tours of the Capitol for student and tourist groups. With two weeks' notice, the Legislative Branch offers an age-appropriate 30-60 minutes presentation on the legislative process, and the Secretary of State's office can present a short program on voting and elections. Self-guided tours are available, as are group tours by reservation. It is recommended that visitors check the calendar on the website at www.visit-the-capitol.mtgov/#tour to choose a date when few visits are already planned. The Capitol is open 7 a.m. to 6 p.m., Monday-Friday and from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday. Call 406-444-4789.

74 Archie Bray Foundation

Sixty years ago, on the grounds of his Western Clay Manufacturing Co. brickyard, Archie Bray founded a pottery workshop to encourage the work and creativity of potters. That simple act became a tremendous resource to ceramic artists, who now flock to the center from around the world. A prominent patron of the arts, Bray died in 1953, only two years after establishing the nonprofit Archie Bray Foundation. Since then, more than 400 artists have come to work and hone their talents at the Bray. It also sells pottery and sculpture. Tours are available. Call 406-443-3502 or visit archiebray.org for event schedules.

75 Myrna Loy Center

In 1976, the Helena Film Society organized to provide alternative films and cinema to residents of the state capital. Based on the second floor of an office building, it became Second Story Cinema and enjoyed a reputation for bringing in independent films. In 1985, with the help of a National Endowment for the Arts grant, the effort expanded with the renovation of the historic Lewis and Clark County Jail into an arts center. The Myrna Loy Center officially opened six years later. Its mission is to present challenging and enriching arts programs to the community. It has sponsored hundreds of live performances, including theater, dance, jazz, folk and performance art. And, yes, it still presents alternative films. For ticket information call 406-443-0287.

76 Marysville

Once a vibrant gold camp with a population of more than 4,000, the town of Marysville northwest of Helena now is nearly a ghost town. Nearly, but not quite. Some people still live here, and a little mining still goes on. Visitors may take a walking tour of the Drumlummon Hill which includes 14 sites, several of which are listed on the National Historic Register. The Catholic church and general store still serve the community and its visitors. The town now is a popular destination for sightseers and those just wanting a pleasant place for a picnic or a quiet day away from the bustle of town.

77 Sun River Canyon

Flowing from Gibson Reservoir, adjacent to the Bob Marshall Wilderness, is the Sun River. The canyon in this area is a spectacular setting for outdoor recreation. The reservoir is popular for boating and fishing. Hunters flock to the area in fall and winter. Boating and scenic tours are available. Situated nearby is the Sun Canyon Lodge, which offers rustic and modern cabins, a restaurant, camping, horseback and wagon rides and boating. This is a great launch site to the Bob Marshall Wilderness and the Rocky Mountain Front.

78 Lincoln

Just a few miles from the Continental Divide, Lincoln is a mountain town that knows how to have fun in any weather. During winter, the area bustles with hunters, snowmobilers, cross-country skiers and dogsledders. Summer brings hikers, backpackers, anglers, photographers, bird watchers, campers, ATVers and others to enjoy the nearby trails, lakes, creeks and Blackfoot River. Take a night drive over nearby Roger's Pass to watch the stars far from city lights. The annual July 4 weekend rodeo draws contestants and fans from around the state. Visit the Blackfoot Valley Historical Society Museum for a taste of the past. Call the Chamber of Commerce at 362-4949 or visit www.lincolnmontana.com.

79 Bob Marshall Wilderness Complex

Encompassing more than 1.5 million acres, the Bob Marshall Wilderness Complex now includes the Bob Marshall, Scapegoat and Great Bear Wilderness areas. The vision for protecting this great swath of mountain country came from Bob Marshall, an early day forester and co-founder of the Wilderness Society. The complex, designated as wilderness in 1964, is now considered one of the most completely preserved mountain ecosystems in the world. It includes rugged mountains ranges, alpine peaks, grassy meadows, fish-heavy streams, large valleys and huge forests. Because of its wilderness designation, the area is not open to motorized traffic. But hikers, backpackers and horse riders all enjoy their trips to the interior. The complex is home to grizzly bears, gray wolves, elk, deer, Canada lynx, bobcats, bighorn sheep, mountain goats, black bears, wolverines and other animals. Access from communities in Gold West Country includes roads near Lincoln, Choteau and Augusta. Plan your visit by visiting www.wilderness.net.

YELLOWSTONE COUNTRY

80 Yellowstone National Park

Yes, the majority of Yellowstone National Park actually is in Wyoming, but three of the park's five entry gates are in Montana's Yellowstone Country: Cooke City, Gardiner and West Yellowstone. The country's first national park was established in 1872. Its 2.2 million acres cover a spectacular array of mountains, lakes, rivers and, of course, geysers, mud caldrons and bubbling hot pots. The natural wonders — from wildlife to geography — are as beautiful in winter as in summer. Especially in the Lamar Valley in the northeast corner, visitors are treated to a wide variety of wildlife, including grizzly bears, wolves, bison, elk and deer. Eagles, falcons and trumpeter swans are among the 303 bird species that make their home in the park.

The Grand Canyon of the Yellowstone is a popular hot spot for tourists and the site of one of the most picturesque glacial and volcanic aftermaths in the world. Visitors will see house-sized boulders and a more-than-300-foot waterfall from which they can view from an overlook directly above.

Entrance fees are $30 for private vehicle, $25 for motorcycle and $15 for visitors on foot or bicycle. It's open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. The park and gateway communities offer lots of accommodations for visitors, but reservations are recommended in the busy tourist seasons. Call 307-344-7381 or visit www.yellowstonenationalparklodges.com.

81 West Yellowstone

The small community of West Yellowstone is a big destination in itself. In the winter, it's known as the Snowmobile Capital of the World — even the local police ride them around town. In summer, it's a busy, busy entranceway to Yellowstone. The town boasts the state's first six-story IMAX theater, with films interpreting the history, wildlife and geothermal activity of Yellowstone Park. Open 8:30 a.m. to 8:30 p.m. every day, the Grizzly and Wolf Discovery Center features live grizzlies and wolves and natural presentations. Beginning in June, there are daily ranger talks, free Smoke Jumper programs for kids, weekend rodeos, a mountain bike biathlon and free fly-fishing clinics. Call 646-7701.

82 Museum of the Rockies

The largest collection of dinosaur fossils from the United States is housed at the Museum of the Rockies in Bozeman at the south side of the MSU campus. The largest T-rex skull, the largest dinosaur skull ever found and some of the world's rarest dinosaurs are on display in the complex which was designed by world-famous paleontologist Jack Horner. As well as the Siebel Dinosaur Complex, the museum houses the Martin Children's Discovery Center, the Taylor Planetarium, Space: A Journey to our Future, Paugh Regional History Hall and the Living History Farm. Three separate halls are dedicated to traveling exhibits. Call 994-2251.

83 Gallatin Gateway

This community just west of Bozeman was named for being a main gateway to Yellowstone National Park. Even in the 1800s, the area was known for its many dude ranches and tourist opportunities. Many out-of-state visitors boarded at the beautiful Gallatin Gateway Inn in the early part of the century. It was restored to its original splendor in recent years and has regained its fame as one of the finest historic Inns in the region. The palatial structure features arched windows and carved beams. The original railroad clock still keeps accurate time for visitors. The Inn now is home to a fine restaurant that draws customers from around the state. Fly fishing is available in the Madison, Gallatin, and Yellowstone rivers and raft trips are available from several guides in the area.

84 Chico Hot Springs

Just 30 miles north of Yellowstone National Park in the foothills of the Absaroka-Beartooth Mountain range is Chico Hot Springs. The resort boasts two hot mineral pools that are enjoyed year round. The turn-of-the-century main lodge has 44 quaint rooms, and individual cabins, chalets and cottages are also available. For diners and dippers, this resort has become known for its fine dining and wide array of day spa services. Call 333-4933.

85 Beartooth Scenic Drive

Charles Kuralt called the Red Lodge to Cooke City Beartooth Scenic Highway the "most scenic drive in America." Normally, only mountain climbers get to see the sights on the drive that, since 1936, has taken visitors over the 11,000-foot Beartooth Pass and past hundreds of tiny ponds, as well as lakes situated in glacial depressions. The Beartooth area is one of the highest and most rugged areas in the lower 48 states, with 20 peaks reaching more than 12,000 feet in elevation. Cross-country skiing may be done during June and July.

86 Beartooth Mountains

Talk about big mountains, the Beartooths offer some of the highest elevations in the lower 48 states. Twenty of its peaks are more than 12,000 feet high. The mountain range offers views of glaciers, lakes, forests and abundant wildlife. Much of the range falls within the 900,000-acre Absaroka-Beartooth wilderness. The wilderness area includes hundreds of miles of trails for plenty of hiking, backpacking and cross-country skiing.

87 Yellowstone Wildlife Sanctuary

Take the north entrance to picturesque Red Lodge to find the sanctuary. Formerly called Beartooth Nature Center, it's the only public facility in the state to house native animals that cannot be returned to the wild because of injury or habituation to humans. More than 70 species reside here, many placed by the Montana Department of Fish, Wildlife & Parks. They include wolves, mountain lions, bears, moose, elk, antelope, bobcats, eagles, hawks and others. The center is open to the public from noon to 4 p.m. Tuesdays-Fridays and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. on weekends, weather permitting, so that visitors can learn about the animals and observe them at close range and through interpretive displays. Call 446-1133.

CUSTER COUNTRY

88 Little Bighorn Battlefield National Monument

In 1876, the U.S. government launched a campaign against Sioux and Cheyenne Indians who refused to be confined within a reservation. Under the spiritual leadership of Sitting Bull, the Indians prepared for battle against the much stronger army. During the preparations, he was said to have conducted a Sun Dance and had a vision of a great victory of the white soldiers. The defeat of Lt. Col. George Armstrong Custer and his 647 soldiers in the 7th Cavalry is now well known. Custer and his men attacked an Indian village in the valley of the Little Bighorn River. When the bloodshed ended, 263 cavalrymen — including Custer — lay dead. Today, the monument lies within the boundaries of the Crow Indian Reservation and commemorates the battle and the warriors on both sides who fought for their respective nations. Summer park hours are 8 a.m.-8 p.m.; the Visitors Center closes at 7:30 p.m. The 4.5-mile driving tour road and Deep Ravine walking trail close at 8 p.m. Call park headquarters at 638-2621 or visitor information at 638-3214.

89 Pompeys Pillar National Monument

On his return trip through southern Montana, explorer Capt. William Clark carved his signature into a 120-foot-high sandstone formation along the Yellowstone River. That signature is preserved for the viewing of guests through the national monument designation. Clark named the pillar after Jean Baptiste "Pomp" Charbonneau, son of Sacagawea, and her guide husband, Toussaint Charbonneau. The child spent the first year and half of his life on the historic journey. Drive in 9 a.m.-6 p.m. until Labor Day; walk in 365 days a year from dawn to dusk. The Interpretive Center closes the last Saturday in September. Call 406-969-5380.

90 Makoshika State Park

Located near Glendive, Montana's largest state park is Makoshika at 11,500 acres. To the Sioux Indians, the name meant "bad earth" or "bad land." Indeed, much of the pine and juniper-studded park is filled with badland formations. The park also is rich in dinosaur remains, including Tyrannosaurus rex and triceratops. A visitor center explains the park's fossils and geologic history. Roads and hiking trails offer visitors a number of routes through which to explore the capstone formations. Visitors also enjoy photography, archery and Frisbee golf. A campground is available, but water is only available May through September. Open daily 10 a.m.-5 p.m. until Labor Day. Call 377-6256.

91 Paddlefishing the Yellowstone

For a unique experience, try your hand catching paddlefish at Yellowstone Intake Diversion Dam just north of Glendive. From mid-May through June, paddlefish run the waters, testing anglers outfitted with heavy-duty tackle and paddlefish licenses. Adult paddlefish weigh from 40 to more than 100 pounds and are prized for the roe. The Glendive Chamber of Commerce collects the roe, which is processed in Glendive and shipped to caviar buyers for distribution to exclusive restaurants.

92 Pictograph Cave State Park

A new sandstone-hued interpretive center rises at the foot of the rimrocks at the park's site seven miles southeast of Billings. The site includes three caves, two of which show pictographic evidence of prehistoric hunters dating back about 4,500 years. A short paved trail takes visitors to within view of the rock paintings still visible. Interpretive signs give details. The site is listed as a National Historic Landmark. A detailed archaeological survey in the 1930s and 40s found graves and more than 30,000 artifacts. Summer hours are 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. Call 254-7342.

93 Musselshell Valley Historical Museum

Nestled in the Musselshell River Valley is Roundup — a cow town if there ever was one. Much of the town's colorful cattle and mining past is captured at the Musselshell Valley Historical Museum. It houses a coal tunnel and memorabilia from early mining days, local Indian artifacts, fossils, restored cowboy and pioneer exhibits, a blacksmith shop and an old ranch home built in the 1880s. New this year is "Clovis to Coal," a display constructed in the rock Room depicting an in-depth history of the geologic Musselshell Valley. Open daily 1-5 p.m. Call 406-323-1525.

94 Miles City

You know you're Out West when you're in Miles City. Once considered a horse trading and livestock center of the country, Miles City still has weekly livestock auctions and lots of cowboy hats around town. Everyone goes cowboy for the annual Bucking Horse Sale in May for rodeo stock buyers and breeders. The Range Riders Museum offers an extensive collection of western artifacts and memorabilia, including more than 400 guns, wagons, restored farm equipment and classic cars. Call 406-234-2890. For refreshments, stop in at the authentically refurbished early 1900s saloon. And, get this — the town has no parking meters!

95 Prairie County Museum and Evelyn Cameron Gallery

search_result.title: Coronavirus in New Jersey: A timeline of events from first cases to ...
search_result.text:
Editor's note: This file will be updated frequently.

New Jersey has been on the front lines of the coronavirus outbreak since January, when Newark Liberty International Airport became a major screening and quarantine station for foreign travelers, to March, when the first New Jerseyans were diagnosed with the disease.

Here is a timeline of events based on news reports and information from the state Department of Health.

March 4

James Cai, a 32-year-old New York physician assistant with an apartment in Fort Lee, is the first person in New Jersey to be diagnosed with coronavirus.

Cai developed symptoms of COVID-19 on March 1, went to an urgent care facility and was eventually admitted to Hackensack University Medical Center.

Cai had not traveled to countries where the virus is spreading, and has no school-aged children. He said he had recently attended a medical conference in Times Square.

After 19 days in the hospital, Cai is eventually released and is recovering at home but still on oxygen because of the lung damage inflicted by the virus. He says that once he is fully recovered, he wants to get back to work and help treat patients.

March 5

An Englewood woman becomes the second New Jerseyan to test positive for coronavirus. The woman, who officials would only say is in her 30s, is treated at Englewood Health and sent home to self-quarantine.

March 6

A Camden County man in his 60s becomes the third New Jersey resident with coronavirus. The man, who had been hospitalized since March 3, is listed in stable condition. Officials said the resident of Cherry Hill had visited Cooper University Urgent Care on Route 70 in Cherry Hill before he was diagnosed.

Later in the day, officials announce that a man, 55, is New Jersey's fourth coronavirus case. He was hospitalized at Englewood Health since March 5. The man had attended the Conservative Political Action Conference in Maryland. President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence also attended the conference, but conference officials said the Englewood man did not interact with Trump or Pence.

Several lawmakers, including Sen Ted Cruz, R-Texas, later said they would self-quarantine out of precaution because they attended the CPAC conference.

March 8

State officials announce New Jersey's fifth and sixth residents to test positive for coronavirus.

One is a 70-year-old Teaneck man whose symptoms began on Feb. 28. The man, a health care worker, was admitted to St. Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson on March 6 and was in stable condition in the intensive care unit. He is the fourth case from Bergen County.

The other resident lives just a few miles south in West New York. The 32-year-old man began showing symptoms on Feb. 28 and entered Hackensack University Medical Center on March 5.

Officials also said two New Jersey patients had received care at CityMD Urgent Care on Route 4 in Paramus when they showed symptoms but had not yet been diagnosed.

March 9

Gov. Phil Murphy declares a state of emergency after five additional residents are diagnosed with the disease, bringing the statewide total to 11.

The declaration allows state government to deploy resources more quickly by waiving a number of bureaucratic requirements like the bidding process for medical supplies.

Murphy says the action is necessary "to ensure that local health agencies on the front lines of the state's response are equipped with the resources needed to further prepare our health care system for a broader spread of COVID-19."

The disease has now been detected in five counties with Bergen having the most: 5.

The new cases included:

An 18-year-old woman from Clifton, who is hospitalized. She may have been in contact with a patient from New York who has the illness.

A 30-year-old Teaneck man, who is hospitalized at Holy Name Medical Center.

A 48-year-old man from Berkeley Heights in Union County, who is at Overlook Medical Center in Summit.

A 27-year-old man in Little Silver, who is not hospitalized. He is among 170 people who attended a conference in Boston and have tested positive.

An 83-year-old woman from Hazlet, who is being treated at Bayshore Medical Center in Holmdel.

HOW IT AFFECTS YOU:NJ declares state of emergency over coronavirus concerns

March 10

Officials announce New Jersey's first coronavirus victim: John Brennan, a 69-year-old Little Ferry man who diedthe morning of March 10 at Hackensack University Medical Center.

The man had a number of underlying health issues including emphysema, diabetes, hypertension, irregular heartbeat and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The man went to his primary care doctor last week with a fever and cough. He was treated with antibiotics and Tamiflu. He was admitted to Hackensack University Medical Center on March 6. He was isolated. His condition deteriorated. He had a heart attack Monday night and was revived, but then died the next morning from a heart attack.

He was a horse trainer and mainstay in the paddock of Yonkers Raceway, according to several horse racing publications.

PROFILE:A passionate horse trainer is NJ's first coronavirus death

He regularly went into New York, but had no recent history of overseas travel.

The man is one of four new cases reported: two in Bergen County and two in Burlington County. The state total is 15.

Bergen County Executive Jim Tedesco announces all county-run technical and specialty schools and Bergen Community College will be closed for two weeks. Visitation at the Bergen County Healthcare and Rehabilitation home for seniors in Rockleigh is suspended.

Rutgers announces it will offer only online courses until at least April 3 and urges students to remain off-campus.

March 11

New Jersey has eight new cases, bringing the total to 23, a day after the state's first death from the virus - just one week since the first patient in New Jersey was diagnosed with the disease.

All of the eight new cases are in hospitals. Four are in Bergen County, two in Middlesex and two in Monmouth counties.

Meanwhile, the World Health Organization's Director-General Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus on March 11 declares the coronavirus outbreak a pandemic as the global death toll rose above 4,300 and the number of confirmed cases exceeded 120,000.

Schools throughout the state begin preparing for possible closures.

Officials announce the postponement of two of New Jersey's largest St. Patrick's Day parades in Morristown and Bergenfield. They will be held in September.

March 12

Large swaths of daily life in New Jersey began shutting down to avoid spread of coronavirus.

Several public school districts announce they will close beginning next week.

The Newark Archdiocese cancels Mass on Sunday and will close schools next week.

Gov. Murphy recommends against holding any gatherings with 250 or more people including concerts and sporting events.

Concert venues like Bergen PAC close. Annual events like the Montclair Film Festival are postponed.

New Jersey courts suspend all new jury trials until further notice.

NJ Transit reports ridership is down 20% on buses and trains, but service will continue to be normal.

Six more corornavirus cases are announced in New Jersey. They include:

A 16-year-old girl from Englewood who was admitted to Englewood hospital

A 66-year-old Montclair woman who is hospitalized at Mountainside Hospital

A 51-year-old Butler man who is hospitalized at Chilton Medical Center who had exposure to someone with the virus

A 23-year-old Bridgewater man who may have been exposed to the virus from close contact to a Pennsylvania patient

A 53-year-old Manalapan man who is hospitalized at CentraState hospital and had exposure to a confirmed case of COVID-19

A female from Teaneck whose age is unknown. Officials didn't know if she was hospitalized. She was exposed at a synagogue carnival on March 1.

Bergen County now has 13 cases - the highest in the state. Officials label the county as a moderate risk.

There are now four cases in Englewood, one Fort Lee resident, two cases in Bergenfield, five cases in Teaneck and one Little Ferry case, a patient who earlier this week had become the first New Jersey resident to die from coronavirus.

Thirty-seven more people statewide are being investigated.

March 13

New Jersey announces 21 new cases, bringing the statewide total to 50.

Of those, two are in Bergen County, which leads the state with 15.

Other new cases were reported in:

Monmouth: 3

Essex: 2

Morris: 2

Hudson: 2

Middlesex: 2

Ocean: 1

Mercer: 1

Burlington: 1

Passaic: 1

No new deaths are reported, but officials say they are investigating whether a recent death was due to coronavirus.

Among those diagnosed is a prominent physician - Dr. James Pruden, head of emergency services at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson.

Murphy said it was inevitable that all schools in the state will soon close for an undetermined amount of time.

Among the day's other developments:

Bergen County orders all movie theaters to close. The county zoo is closed. American Dream will be shut down for a month.

The state is expected to receive 84,000 respirators, 200,000 surgical face masks and thousands of face shields for health care workers.

All residents who have their driver’s license, auto registration, or vehicle inspection due for renewal by May 31 will receive a two-month extension.

All utility shut-off orders for customers with unpaid bills have been suspended for the time being.

The state is working to receive federal waivers to ensure that schoolchildren in districts retain access to a healthy lunch that they normally would have received at school.

March 14

Gov. Murphy announces the second coronavirus death in New Jersey - a woman in her 50s who was being treated at CentraState Medical Center in Monmouth County.

The number of coronavirus cases continues to climb in New Jersey, as testing becomes more available. The state reports 19 new cases bringing the total to 69 statewide.

Teaneck officials call for all residents to self-quarantine and only leave their residences for food and medicine as the township grapples with the most coronavirus cases (18) in the state.

Officials are working to set up a "widespread testing center" at Bergen Community College in Paramus.

Hospitals begin taking more steps to contain and test for the virus.

St. Joseph’s Medical Center in Paterson begins barring visitors.

Holy Name Medical Center in Teaneck and Morristown Hospital erect tents outside to test for coronavirus.

Some towns begin ordering the closure of businesses that attract many people. Hoboken closes gyms, day care centers and movie theaters along with playgrounds and ballfields.

State prisons suspend visits for 30 days.

March 15

The number of coronavirus cases in New Jersey shoots up to 98 with 31 new cases added.

Bergen County had seven new cases, for a total of 32 cases, according to the site, and Monmouth and Middlesex counties each have 12.

Gov. Murphy says he is considering more aggressive steps — including closing all schools statewide and a possible curfew — to slow the spread.

Hospitals continue to burn through supplies of personal protective equipment. Holy Name Medical Center, at the center of the outbreak in Teaneck, is using 700 to 1,000 sets of masks, gowns, face shields and gloves daily.

With at least 18 cases in Teaneck the most of any one town in New Jersey, local officials order the closing of many businesses including restaurants, bars, gyms, nail salons and other places where larger groups gather. The order allows only one member of a family to enter a supermarket at one time to limit the number of people.

Bergen County officials say they are considering a similar order for the county's other 69 municipalities.

The Motor Vehicle Commission announces it will close for two weeks.

Towns that have bustling restaurant scenes like Montclair and Hoboken order restaurants to provide only takeout meals.

March 16

A 90-year-old man becomes New Jersey's third coronavirus casualty, Gov. Phil Murphy announces. The Saddle Brook man died from complications due to the coronavirus at Hackensack University Medical Center.

New Jersey officials announce 80 new coronavirus cases bringing the statewide total to 178. It is the biggest surge yet.

A wide range of businesses in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut are ordered to close indefinitely at 8 p.m.: restaurants, bars, movie theaters, casinos and gyms.

Bergen County Executive James Tedesco orders all malls in the county to close.

Gov. Phil Murphy mobilizes the National Guard to help in containment efforts.

Murphy asks New Jerseyans not to leave their homes from 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. to help avoid the spread of coronavirus.

Restaurants can offer takeout and delivery services. Supermarkets, pharmacies, gas stations and medical offices will remain open.

Gatherings of 50 or more people are not allowed.

As expected, Murphy orders all schools statewide to close.

Edgewater and Leonia tell students and staff at two schools (George Washington and Anna C. Scott) to self-quarantine after staff members test positive for the virus.

State officials announce that all state parks would remain open for "healthful passive recreation."

March 17

St. Patrick's Day comes to New Jersey with few, if any, public celebrations as bars close the night before.

Gov. Phil Murphy announces all malls and indoor amusement centers to close as the state's coronavirus cases rise to 267 as more testing is done.

Other retail stores begin curtailing their hours.

The Attorney General's Office warns 82 more businesses over price gouging for coronavirus.

Officials make preparations to open two drive-thru test sites at Bergen Community College in Paramus and the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel.

Hoboken requires residents to stay at home unless they are traveling for work, getting food or exercising in what appears to be the strictest restrictions on movement in New Jersey since the coronavirus outbreak.

March 18

Two more New Jerseyans die in the coronavirus outbreak, bringing the statewide total to five. Both were women (one from Essex County, one from Hudson County) over 60 years old and had other underlying medical conditions.

Officials also announce 162 cases for a total of 427 statewide.

Bergen County continues to be the virus epicenter for the state, with 27 new cases, for a total of 113.

About 55% of all cases are or were hospitalized.

Gov. Phil Murphy says New Jersey could be short by upwards of 300,000 hospital beds in the coming months and doctors may be forced to make the "agonizing" decision to deny care to victims of COVID-19 if the state doesn't get federal help.

Offiicals say they are working to reopen Underwood Memorial Hospital in Woodbury, Gloucester County, with a 300-bed capacity for acute care.

Gun store owners report sales are up especially from first-time buyers.

March 19

State officials confirm another four deaths related to complications from coronavirus as new cases statewide surge by 318 to a total of 742.

The four deaths are:

Bergen County man in his 30s

Monmouth County woman, 70s

Ocean County man, 70s

Essex County man, 60s

While health officials say those at greatest risk from the virus are over 60 years old and have underlying medical conditions, the youngest case so far in New Jersey is a 3-year-old child. The oldest is 95.

Bergen County continues to be the virus epicenter for the state, with 194 cases, a jump of 80 on Wednesday. Essex County has 62 people with the disease, Middlesex has 60, Hudson has 54 and Monmouth has 45.

A record number of New Jerseyans are applying for unemployment benefits. From March 8 to March 14, claims jumped nearly 21 percent to 9,467 compared to the same week in 2019.

NJ Transit officials request a $1.25 billion bailout to account for losses the agency is experiencing with ridership down 88%.

Gov. Phil Murphy signs a law and executive order that prevents residents from being evicted or losing their homes to foreclosure during the crisis.

Murphy also orders the closing at 8 p.m. of personal care businesses that can't comply with social distancing, such as barbers, salons and tattoo parlors.

Elections for March and April are pushed back to May 12 and will be only vote-by-mail.

An employee at an immigration detention facility in Elizabeth tests positive for thecoronavirus.

March 20

New Jersey reports 2 new deaths related to complications of the coronavirus bringing the total to 11, while the number of cases statewide increased to 890, with 155 new cases.

Among the new deaths are a Bergen County man in his 50s and an Essex County man in his 30s.

In Paramus, hundreds of drivers in cars line up in the early morning hours outside Bergen County College to be tested for coronavirus as the largest testing facility in North Jersey opens.

Health workers manage to test 654 at the site before shutting down operations.

The National Guard is sent in to assist with crowd control.

March 21

Gov. Phil Murphy orders all nonessential businesses to close indefinitely and orders nearly all residents to stay home starting at 9 p.m. Saturday.

He also cancels gatherings of any number, including parties, weddings and religious ceremonies, joining New York, Pennsylvania, California and other states taking more draconian measures to stop the surging levels of the novel coronavirus

Businesses offering essential services will remain open, including grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, hardware stores, laundromats, pet stores, mail and restaurants that offer only takeout out and delivery.

Murphy announces five new deaths caused by complications related to coronavirus bringing the total 16. They are

a man in his 50s from Monmouth County

a man in his 80s from Essex County

a man in his 40s from Bergen County

a man in his 90s from Bergen County

a woman in her 70s from Morris County

In Bergen County, the state’s first mass testing center for coronavirus is declared to be at capacity 15 minutes after opening Saturday as hundreds of cars stood in line for the site’s second day of operation.

Flights in and out of the New York region are halted for a brief time after an alert was issued because of staffing issues with an air traffic control tower at JFK International Airport. An air traffic controller trainee tested positive and the control tower had to sanitized.

March 22

As the state shuts down, New Jersey reports 4 more deaths related to complications from the virus, bringing the statewide total to 20.

There are also 590 new cases of the virus, bringing the statewide total to 1,914.

Coronavirus starts spreading at local jails and other institutions.

The Hudson County jail goes on lockdown after two inmates test positive for the coronavirus.

Fifteen Bergen County jail inmates are placed in quarantine as a precautionary measure after a corrections officer tested positive for COVID-19.

Staff at New Jersey's state psychiatric hospitals are taking steps to "contain and mitigate" the spread of coronavirus after a doctor and patient at Greystone Park in Parsippany tested positive for the virus.

March 23

New Jersey's deaths related to coronavirus continue to climb, reaching 27 with seven new deaths;

Total cases rise to 2,844 with 935 new cases as testing continues to accelerate.

Among the new deaths are five men and two women, aged 57 to 91. Two had preexisting medical conditions. The deaths included:

two Bergen County residents

one Essex County resident

one Passaic County resident

one Union County resident

one Warren County resident

one Somerset County resident

Meanwhile, state officials continue to make dramatic moves to contain the spread.

Up to 1,000 inmates serving sentences in county jails will be temporarily released, under an order by New Jersey Chief Justice Stuart Rabner.

It calls for the release no later than 6 a.m. Tuesday of inmates who are serving county jail terms as a condition of probation or as a result of municipal court convictions.

No later than noon Thursday, any inmate serving county jail sentences for any other reason, including violations of probation, low-level indictable crimes, disorderly persons and petty disorderly persons offenses, will be released.

Gov. Phil Murphy orders all elective surgeries and invasive procedures for adults – both medical and dental – effective 5 p.m. on March 3/27. This applies to all operations that can be safely delayed, as determined by the patient’s doctor or dentist.

Close to $1 billion in state spending is frozen as an effort to keep the state afloat amid the pandemic.

March 24

The number of New Jersey residents who have died from coronavirus increases to 44 total out of 3,675 cases.

The new deaths include:

5 Bergen County residents

3 Morris

3 Essex

2 Hudson

1 Monmouth

1 Union

1 Passaic

1 Camden

Gov. Phil Murphy says the state is getting another shipment of protective equipment from the national stockpile including 200,000 N95 masks and more than 84,000 respirators.

The Bergen County testing site at Bergen Community College reaches capacity before it opens, marking the fifth day in a row the site reached capacity early.

March 25

The death toll from coronavirus rises from 44 to 62 and the number of cases increases by 736 to 4,402.

Here is the county breakdown of the 18 new deaths:

Ocean (4)

Essex (3)

Monmouth (2)

Bergen (1)

Burlington (1)

Cumberland (1)

Hudson (1)

Middlesex (1)

Morris (1)

Passaic (1)

Somerset (1)

Union (1)

Gov. Phil Murphy orders all childcare centers to close by April 1 unless they can certify that they are caring only for the children of essential workers.

A mass testing site for Passaic County is opened at William Paterson University. It is not nearly as crowded as its Bergen counterpart because it is open only to Passaic County residents who have a doctor's note.

March 26

Officials announce 2,492 additional cases - by far the highest total for a single day. There are now 6,876 cases in New Jersey.

Officials report 19 new deaths, bringing the total to 81.

New Jersey has an infection rate of 31.7% with 6,137 positive tests out of 19,364 tests performed.

The state's 43 of its 375 long term care facilities lie nursing homes have at least one resident who has tested positive.

President Donald Trump approves a Major Disaster Declaration for New Jersey, making federal funding available to the state to aid in the response to the coronavirus outbreak.

March 27

New Jersey officials report 27 new deaths for a total of 108. Total cases surge to 8,825 with 1,982 new cases.

That's a 17,500% increase from two weeks ago when total cases statewide were only 50.

New deaths were reported in the following counties:

Bergen (7)

Middlesex (4)

Essex (3)

Monmouth (3)

Ocean (3)

Somerset (3)

Morris (2)

Hudson (1)

Gloucester (1)

Murphy calls on anyone with medical experience to help volunteer at four new field hospitals at the Meadowlands Exposition Center in Secaucus, the Atlantic City Convention Center, and the New Jersey Convention and Exposition Center in Edison, which will have two units.

Ten federal immigration detainees with chronic health conditions are set free from the Bergen, Essex and Hudson county jails after a judge orders they be released because they face serious risks of death or injury if they remain confined.

A day after announcing that it will close three large parks, Bergen County orders all parks to close to limit transmission.

In a bit of good news, one of the first medical workers to be infected is recovering after being in critical condition. Dr. James Pruden, 70, of St. Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson is breathing on his own for the first time in weeks.

March 28

New Jersey officials report 2,289 new positive COVID-19 cases for a statewide total of 11,124.

There are 32 more deaths for a total of 140. The breakdown by county is:

Bergen (7)

Union (7)

Middlesex (5)

Morris (3)

Essex (2)

Hudson (2)

Passaic (2)

Ocean (1)

Somerset (1)

Sussex (1)

Warren (1)

Murphy announces that five major banks and state-chartered institutions in New Jersey will offer a 90-day grace period on residential mortgage payments for borrowers impacted by the coronavirus outbreak.

Murphy also announces $146 million in funding to help hospitals prepare for the surge in patients.

New Jersey is requiring all hospitals and medical facilities to provide a daily update on their supplies of protective medical equipment, including ventilators, and to report how many patients are hospitalized.

President Trump suggests that he would quarantine New York, New Jersey and parts of Connecticut. But hours later after some questioned whether he had the legal authority to do so, Trump pulls back and said the region was under a an advisory to avoid all non-essential travel - a policy that had already been in place in each state.

March 29

Gov. Phil Murphy announces 2,316 new positive cases and 21 new deaths throughout New Jersey, which has the second largest outbreak behind New York.

The state now has 13,386 total cases including 161 known deaths. New York has nearly 60,000 cases and is approaching 1,000 deaths, statewide.

Around 700 police officers throughout New Jersey have tested positive for the coronavirus.

March 30

Officials announce 3,347 additional cases resulting in 16,636 total statewide. Only New York has a higher statewide number.

There are 37 new deaths related to coronavirus bringing New Jerseys total to 198.

Gov. Phl Murphy says New Jersey will run out of ICU beds to care for coronavirus patients within the next two weeks unless the public increases the practice of social distancing to historically unprecedented levels.

Officials have been warning of infections spreading at nursing homes for weeks and it now becomes deadly.

Eight residents of Lakeland Health Care Center in Wanaque died from the virus in recent days, officials announce.

The United States Naval Hospital Ship Comfort arrives in New York to treat patients sufferng from something other than COVID19 to take pressure off area hospitals.

March 31

New Jersey sees its highest jump in deaths - 69 - brining the statewide total tp 267.

Among them are two young men: Passaic firefighter Israel Tolentino, 33, and Cliffside Park baseball coach Ben Luderer, 30.

Officals also announce 2,196 additional cases for a statewide total of 18,696 cases.

New Jersey has done a total of 44,330 tests with 38.92% of the tests coming back positive.

Longterm care facilities remain a big concern for New Jersey. Of the 375 longterm care facilities in the state, 81 have confirmed at least one coronavirus case.

April 1

Officials say the expected and dreaded surge of coronavirus cases is beginning as the death toll continues to increase sharply each day.

Officials say 91 people died over the past 24 hours for a total of 355 since the outbreak began.

The number of coronavirus cases rises by 3,649 for a statewide total of 22,255.

Officials begin trying to secure refrigerated trucks to hold the dead.

Nursing homes continue to be hard hit.

More than 70 residents of long-term care facilities have died from the virus, accounting for 21% of the state’s 355 total deaths due to coronavirus.

Across the state, more than 70 residents of long-term care facilities have died from the virus, accounting for 21% of the state’s 355 total deaths due to coronavirus as of Wednesday.

April 2

The death toll increases substantially with 182 new deaths for a statewide total of 537.

There are 3,489 additional cases for 25,590 statewide.

Unemployment continues to grow exponentially.

Officials report that a record 206,253 New Jerseyans filed for unemployment insurance last week in the immediate days following mass business closures, banned gatherings and a stay-at-home order to try to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

Workers finish building a 250-bed field hospital, the first of four planned for New Jersey, at the Meadowlands Exposition Center in Secaucus. It will take patients from hospitals to make room in those hospitals for coronavirus patients during the expected surge.

April 3

Murphy orders all flags to fly at half-mast in honor of the victims until the emergency is lifted.

New Jersey reports 113 new deaths for a statewide total of 646.

Total coronavirus cases rise to 29,895 with 4,372 additional cases.

April 4

The death toll keeps rising to near-unimaginable levels just a few weeks ago.

New Jersey reports 200 new deaths. That brings the statewide total to 846, surpassing the number of NJ fatalities on 9/11.

The new deaths are in the following counties:

Bergen (47)

Essex (37)

Warren (3)

Sussex (1)

There are 4,331 additional cases fora total of 34,124 cases statewide.

In order to avoid overburdening Jersey Shore medical facilities, Murphy signs an order that allows towns and counties to restrict short term rentals and keep residents in their primary home.

April 5

Officials announce 3,482 new cases for a total of 37,505.

Officials also report 71 new deaths Sunday. There have been 917 deaths related to coronavirus in New Jersey. These are the totals by county as of April 5:

Bergen (189)
